content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Men of War Assault Squad is the best WW2 real-time tactics game! I've been following this game series ever since the original 'Soldiers Heroes of WW2'. When I tried the demo back then, and realized that you can take the shells out of your broken tank to load a stolen anti-tank gun, and you can scavenge the fallen bodies for weapons and ammunition, and you can take cover behind virtually everything, and you can drive tanks through buldings, I was immediately sold. This amazing level of detail and authenticity is still present today, and it brings an immense level of control and different tactics that you can use. That comes at the expense of very much micromanagement and almost every key on the keyboard being assigned to some action. That makes it hard for newcomers to pick up, but once you memorized everything, you're going to have a blast. The multiplayer component is a bit shaky, because it uses an old GameSpy service. That's why I have very high hopes for the upcoming Assault Squad 2, which promises to have full Steam MP integration. The developers have been listening to the community a lot and have published several free updates with lots of new content, so I trust them on this one.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												Im on the back foot...Enemy infantry made it past my front line, a situation that comprimises my whole team, I purchase and sent out a Half-Track with mounted .50 caliber heavy machine gun to clear them up..  however on the way an the debries from a building hit by artilery hits happens to hit and take out the gunner..  Time for a bit of fast micro..  Upon reaching the area the enemy was last spotted there is no sign of them, they have likely scattered into various cover (all units in a squad can be indivudually controlled in fine detail or directly controlled) ..  I spot an enemy half track! The hole in my front line is bigger than I thought. I decide to play rambo with my driver, I dismount, detatch the .50 cal gun from it with my driver and take some TNT from the back. I command my soldier to only return fire preventing him from opening fire and giving away his location, I tell him to get down on the ground and crawl to a nearby bush. I know my empty half track presents an irristable target for the enemy to steal... the bait and trap set,  I switch my attention to re-enforcing my front lines, perhaps a sniper to spot and an AT-gun patch up the line, cant afford more infantry yet, I spread my lines a little thinner.I spot the red dots in my backline on my mini map, lucky I caught it!  Switching back to Rambo in time to see the enemy attempt to jack my halftrack. I put him in direct contrtol more, and take my time aiming a perfect shot at the enemy half track approaching, some men already disembarking and running for my bait..  FIRE.. ♥♥♥♥♥♥I mis-judged the distance! He's far enough away that my trusty .50 Cal cannot penetrate his armour, backup plan, I aim for his tracks as he turns to escape.. come on.. yes! I manage to break the track off the left side, disabling his movement. A man hops out to begin repairs...  I put a .50 Cal in his skull.. he won't try that again. I mow down enemy infantry spotted until I've run out of bullets. I switch to my pistol, move into an impact crator recently created, there I hide hoping to find an oppertunity to use the TNT to maximise damage. Rambo has played his part... but all the while I have been equally creative with any of the hundred odd units on the field....

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Men of War: Assault Squad is a real time tactical/strategy game that takes place in all fronts in World War II. The game is different from other World War II strategy games that relies on direct control (having the ability to actually control a unit), tank realism, and individual micromanagement. The game requires a strong ability of militaristic tactics such as flaking, taking cover, support, and other attributes. Assault Squad is a terrific strategy game in its own merits, but a few flaws might make you consider to get this game or not.One of the most greatest parts in the game is the importance of tanks. I reallly mean it. Obviously, tanks can shoot infantry and blow up things. In Assault Squad, tanks is, without a doubt, the main essential to victory. Nearly the majority of "skirmishes" requires the player to push and capture 10 control points. It is possible to take 10 control points with only infantry and support classes, but it will be very, very difficult to substain the enemy AI's counterattacks with medium and heavy tanks that will crush your forces. Tank damages is top notch and highly realistic. Assault Squad can be explained in one sentence: Infantry is the soul of your forces, but tanks is the body to move your forces to win. Another positive attribute is its immersion. The environment looks good for a 2011 game. It's not the best looking game in today's standards, but it does look pretty neat to look at. Most strategy games have a limit cap on how many units you can have, but Assault Squad does not have such cap. It's not unlimited, but you can have a lot of units under your command. Lastly, the direct control mode is really helpful when your squad cannot take out a certain position. It'll relieve you some stress in dire situations and turn these situations into your advantage. There are some flaws in Assault Squad. One of the major problems is the AI, the enemy and your forces. The enemy AI is not stupid, but it can be very frustrating and, occasionally, exploitive. The problem is that the AI would send in two medium and one heavy tanks and 20+ infantry every two minutes as reinforcement. Sure, it does not sound that bad, but Assault Squad requires the player to be "aggressive". You can take a capture point, one at a time, and just hold your position until the enemy stops (or slows) their counterattack against you before you can start taking another control point. However, this will only increase stress. The enemy AI is really, I mean really, smart on targeting the weak spots on your tanks. Prepare to get upset when the enemy destroys most of your tanks in one or two shots. In the other hand, your tanks is not very smart. They tend to show its sides to the enemy, saying: "Hey enemy, shoot me in the back. I'm open". Basically, the tank AI is not very smart. Another flaw in Assault Squad is punishing difficulty. There are four difficulty modes: Easy, Normal, Hard, and Heroic. The problem is that Normal Mode is not normal at all. Normal mode is really difficult for moderate players who have a decent amount of playing other RTS or standard strategy games. Hard mode requires very aggressive gameplay mechanics, but Heroic is the impossible. Literally impossible. The difficult gap is very wide and the enemy AI enjoys throwing very tough enemy units to rout your forces and probably requires you to conduct unorthodox methods to win. Assault Squad has no mission varieties besides of capturing 10 control points missions and standard defense missions (then control 3 enemy positions). Basically, no mission varieties. Unfortunately, the multiplayer in this game is dead because of GameSpy ceaes to exist so I wasn't able to play multiplayer to get the experience. The flaws in the game sounds very discouraging, but it's not a turn off. Assault Squad is a fine tactical strategy game and relies on strategic thinking and tactical methods. Men of War is not your standard strategy game and will appeal to certain audience within the strategy game community. Do I recommend this game to other strategy players? Yes, if you only play single player since multiplayer died. If you are looking for multiplayer, then you can get the sequel, Men Of War: Assault Squad 2 instead. It is best to only get the game when it is on -75% off, nothing else since the community in the first Assault Squad barely exist.

You have an Action Shooter!1337/10 - "Would kill Nazis and take their hats again." - IGN

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												**5/18/14 Update**It is reality, Gamespy will be shutting down as of May 31, 2014, When Gamespy shuts down, MP for Men of war , other than AS2 , will be dead. People mention 3rd party programs you can use for matchmaking after the shut down. That is not practical as those 3rd party programs won't be as safe. The issue has been brought up, why not just use Steamworks for MP? That's a very valid question, the reality of the situation is, the company that makes this, is lazy, and would rather force everyone to buy their new game. Truly unfortunate because Assault Squad 1 is one of my favourite strategy games of all time, heck, even one of my most favourite games of all time. To see a company do this when they had the chance to show they support their community and their games, is truly unfortunate. Who is to say they won't do the same thing to AS2 in a few months?**4/8/14 Update to Review**Recently announced, Men of War: Assault Squad, will not be playable in multiplayer after May 31st 2014, the game creator is ending it's steam support for MOWAS, aswell as the earlier versions of the series. Their explination seems to stem from "We're unable to provide support, but, you can purchase Men of War: Assault Squad 2, and it will be fine" , that in itself seems fishy, but overall I leave people's interpretation of that move up to them. The game review still stands, tis a great and fun game, but all in all, the company's descision to end multiplayer essentially kills the game unless you're willing to risk using a 3rd party software for MP. Telling your customers to simply "Purchase the new game" instead of continuing support of your recent products, is an unfortaunte situation for everyone that enjoys MOWAS1 , so buyers beware. If the company comes out with a new game in a year that's based on the Men of War series, you could be looking at this happening again. I personally am retiring from the Men of War series over this move. Very, VERY toxic business move.A very, very in depth RTS that is more historically accurate and well put together than games of the same Genre (IE Company of autists) , You will not be dissappointed if you're looking for a quality, well made RTS based around WW2 with a few extra easter eggs thrown in. (Christmas mission to defend against the grinch, ect.) Not for those new to RTS's but it does have a tutorial that will show you the ropes. Multiplayer can be a challenge as there are several instances of a little lag, and others not speaking english, other than that, MP offers 1 on 1 up to 8 on 8 matches where you can lay down some serious hurt. Squads can be broken up into 1 man detachments or anything in beetween, different level of infantry can mean the difference beetween conscripts equipped with pea shooters to elite troops with body armor and assault rifles and are fully trained. Vehicles and artillery can range from a simple machine gun or jeep, to a 60 ton late war tank or heavy artillery, how you field your army is up to you , use them wisely!

												     This game is an amazing game. It has hundreds of hours of play value between the Campaign missions and the Editor. Plus, mods such as the Cold War mod make this game even better. Although there are some things to be considered when buying.     Pros:               -Great WWII combat with in depth gameplay and hours of fun              -In depth editor that allows you to create maps and missions              -Great mods to add to the fun    Cons:              - No multiplayer due to Gamespy's shutdown (Unless through a 3rd party program)              -Graphics quality, while decent, is not as good as it could be     TBH, It is worth the $3 you pay to get it, but with a lack of multiplayer, it might be best to get Men of War: Assault Squad 2 for better graphics and multiplayer as well as new stuff.

Posted: March 6, 2016
												This is a strategy/tatical game. I have always been sceptic to it. Probably because I never gave it a real shot. It can't be compared to Company of Heroes and shouldn't be. The game has a very realisitic damage table which means that an infantary dies just after 1-3 hits. Facing a tank can be a deadly outcome which can whipe a squad within seconds. I strongly recommend that you start off by playing the easy campaign to learn the basic and still be able to enjoy the game.+ Realistic damage + Slower, tatical warfare + Real WW2 weapons and vehicles. + Control units (WASD+Mouse) or run, walk, phrone, suppressing fire etc. - The missions are quite fun but they don't give you many units to play around with. The Germans doesn't have air support (famous stuka?) or any of their famous arty guns. - Missions are too similar. No big change in layout- AI are really buggy and stupid. You tell a vehicle to drive from A to B and it get stuck half way. - The resupply system could have done automatic. I'm talking about  letting a soilder go back and forth to resupply an artiliitery for e.g. This is something you need to do manually and having 2-3 arty's takes time to do. I don't mind that it takes time but you leave the whole battlefield open because you are busy to resupply guns. - Multiplayer could have been so much better developed. Overall I think this game lack of hungry developers. It seems lke they are happy about how the game runs or not runs. IMO if they actually spent money and time to come up with a new fresh multiplayer, fix the AI's. a better hotkey system (QWERTY) this game can easily be a top strat game. At current state 7/10 because it cost less then a dollar.

number of helpful: 20 of 27 people (74%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Men of War: Assault Squad is a World War II strategy game developed by Digitalmindsoft and published by 1C Company and was released in February 2011. You, the player, play as different countries from WW2 in historically accurate battles and complete this battles by capturing a set number of strategic points on the battlefield. I will write this review from a single-player perspective by only playing skirmishes, as I did not play this game online or with friends. It will discuss skirmishes, the gameplay within these skirmishes, the graphics and performance, and the overall recommendation.The main feature of Assault Squad is an underwhelming skirmish mode. A skirmish is a play through recount of a historical battle that is chronological, therefore, there is no proper story campaign. However, there is a recount of the story in the loading screen prior to battle. The skirmishes are split into six categories of America, Germany, Japan, Soviet Union, Britain, and bonus missions, so there is a nice balance of skirmishes. The skirmishes are decent at best, but there is laziness in the mode. The objectives are identical in each mission and country skirmish, which is unfortunate because there is variety in the side missions that add to the skirmish tasks. I did not finish all skirmishes because the lack of variety does not add an incentive for me to complete them, hurting the overall playability of the game. But, I do like the accuracy of the history and the realistic environments within the campaign because the environment adapts as the battle rages on. For instance, if an artillery shell hits the ground it creates a nice and massive hole to showcase the damage. Overall, the skirmishes are a let-down due to the lack of variety.The gameplay is solid. I commend the developer for making small things count to add to the realistic nature of the game. For instance, a soldier can die in one hit. Furthermore, the gameplay has a very nice strategic concept as a vehicle out powers infantry, though the infantry can flank and destroy the vehicle. The game strikes a good balance between automation and micromanaging, as your soldiers run out of ammo so you have to go to dead bodies and collect ammo, which evenly distributes that ammo among the entire squad. This balance allows the game not to be bogged down by the micromanagement concept, as the battle is real-time and you can easily lose units. Assault Squad has limitations through the type of available units. For instance, each country has unique units, accurate with the historical counterparts, but there is not a wide variety of different units for the player to choose. While this does not overly hurt the game, it could have been expanded upon.Assault Squad compensates for an underwhelming skirmish mode by having strong graphics and optimised performance. The graphics capture the tone of WW2 through the environment, such as the smoke that arises after a vehicle has been destroyed. Further, the graphics are beautiful when showcasing buildings and the realism of them. Likewise, the performance is great as I run consistently at a 60FPS on ultra-settings.Men of War: Assault Squad is an overall average game. The skirmish mode is underwhelming mainly due to the lack of variety in objectives. The gameplay is solid in that it is very realistic, which it should be for a WW2 game. The graphics and performances are very good. There were not any notable issues, but the game did not wow me nor did I think the game was good. The lack of incentive to continue playing the game hurt my playability of it. However, there is enough content for others to play this for a long time. I played this game for 15 hours but there is enough content to play through to 30 hours, and with friends at least 60 hours of fun. I played the original Men of War and I liked that, but I felt this was a downgrade. I recommend this game on sale.Skirmishes: 4/10Gameplay: 5.5/10Graphics and performance: 8/10Replayability: 7/10Overall: 6/10Thanks for reading my review! If you liked it, give it a rating. If you liked this review, join my review group. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews If you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page.

												When you get right down to it, Men of War: Assault Squad is a tactical WWII RTS game for those who have mastered the somewhat easier-to-handle Company of Heroes. This is a challenging battlefield experience somewhat closer to a wargame than to a traditional RTS game and as such is geared to more of a hardcore crowd. It isn't such a great option for tank rushers who don't have a lot of time to spare to learn combined-arms intricacies. Be aware of these demands going in, and you will have a great time refighting this war.This review is "For Uncle Sam!"

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
Men of War: Assault Squad Review - Rating: 8.2/10General ImpressionMen of War: Assault Squad is a nice strategy game. The graphics are nice, everything looks more realistic, compared to the older Men of War games, and also the textures have been improved. The atmosphere mostly happens in open fields, villages, cities, forests, and even other environments. The audio is pretty nice. I like the sound of the guns, tanks, etc. The music is nice, the ambient music turns into combat music well-synchronized, and it’s overall sounding nice. It sounds less patriotic than the older Men of War titles, but I guess times have changed. The voice acting is also pretty nice. The gameplay is complex, in each mission you have to accomplish some tasks, alike killing certain enemies, cleaning fields off enemies, destroying some units, reaching a point, capturing a point, holding off certain positions, etc. The story focuses on the Soviet, German, Allied and Japan forces during World War 2. The game has 6 campaign, the 6th one of them being the bonus missions. What I don’t like about the missions: they are repetitive. Most of the missions have the same tasks, just different enemies and environments. For some gamers, the missions will get boring after a while. For me, they didn’t get repetitive too much. But, in other reviews, many people have complained about the repetitive missions. The cut scenes of the missions are also pretty nice. The user interface is well-optimized, with no bugs and well-synthetized information. I also like the overall design of it. The controls are pretty good, except with 1 thing: the rotations’ controls of the cameras. I highly recommend you to reset them with the arrow buttons. The engines, just like in every Men of War game, are not perfect. The game has rarely crashes, and when it crashes, you obviously lose the progress of your mission. Try and save the game as often as you can, in order to avoid too much progress lose. You don't want to waste your time by restarting the mission from zero, right? The mechanics are sophisticated, being pretty nice and everything moves well-optimized. Now, I’m going to talk a little about the G.E.M. editor. Just like in every Men of War game, you have a G.E.M. editor. You can create your own battles in it. It is complex and with a various number of functions. This game has brought it more forces from the Earth, more units per each country and overall you will have more diversified fun. Overall, this game is a nice strategy game which simulates the battles of the Soviet, German, Allied and Japan forces during World War 2.Positive PointsNice and well-designed graphics and texturesPretty nice audio and nice musicFun and challenging gameplayMany missions throughout the 6 campaigns availableInfantry, heavy guns, batteries, cannons, vehicles, tanks, airplanes, and many other units available 4 difficulties available (the heroic difficulty is new into the Men of War series)A pretty nice designed user interface, and some well-designed cut scenesSome pretty stable enginesSome pretty nice mechanicsNeutral PointsTrading cards would be a nice featureThe heroic difficulty should be easier, it is almost unplayableNegative PointsThe new types of missions are repetitiveThe multiplayer is not alive anymoreThere are some rare crashes, like in all the Men of War games

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												It was cold, very cold, our orders were simple: survive. it was January and the russian winter was ending or so it seemed, our armored divison arrived 3 hours late, Mud they claimed but we knew it wasnt mud, no, not mud it was plain simple it was fear. The russians were infamous for jumping out of the treeline with rockets and molotovs a real pain for our tanks. As the snow begain to stop and my vison cleared it began. zooop! bullets rained around everywhere it was the russians one after another bullets flew past and screams became louder, this was it but why? why am i so scared? i signed up for this to fight for the Fatherland. Engines roared as the panzers drove past and the cannons blasted ripping trees and slinging dirt and debris into the sky  Waiting paitently with my sniper i look down my scope and see him, a boy 19 0r 20 a sad face, i understand him i.. i am him at this moment, but honor for my people kicks into my mind and i squeese the trigger. i hear a loud pop and see a body drop suddenly he is dead.. Pop... my ribs they hurt why? why do i feel so good? i look over to see a russian soldier with his Mosin aimed at me and i look down to see a crimson red in my  chest i look up and yell Fur das Vaterland! Now im cold and lost will you guide me to war? or have i saw the end to it? 10/10 Fun strategy Game.

content:
Posted: January 14
												This game blurs the line between reality and fiction. I'm just kidding,it doesn't! But it does blur the line between a strategy game and a tactical shooter. The game's intro is somewhat difficult when you're new to the game, and I forgot the game WAS a RTS until about halfway through the battle. I had a lot of fun with it, sending a single soldier to break through the lines,only for him to become pinned down,then relieved by his squadmates. I saw that same squad pinned down,far ahead of the main force, desperate attempts at a armored counterattack,and wearing down the enemy's tenacious defenses. I hope that you get the same experience because this is truly a great game,and a great RTS.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Men of War: Assault Squad is a real-time strategy from Digitalmindsoft and published by 1C Company. Men of War: Assault Squad is considered a sequel to the previous game Men of War.Men of War: Assault Squad retain the same element of gameplay from Men of War, which is micromanagement. But unlike the first Men of War, Men of War: Assault Squad offers a skirmish based mission rather than a story based campaign. This skirmish game is a capture the flag type game which you need to capture all the enemy flag position to win the game. New units and weapons has been added, and for the first time in Men of War series, Japanese faction has been fully added to the game with voice acting, vehicles and weapons of their own. The game also comes with an editor in which you can make your own skirmish based mission or make your new story based mission.Graphics of Men of War: Assault Squad has been improved. Explosion effects, sounds, weapons tracer, even the vehicles and weapons model are all improved. As the game being patched, new weapons and new vehicles are being added to the game. The game still runs pretty smooth with all these upgraded graphics. And Men of War series is the only game where you can hear an American soldier saying "for the Motherland".The multiplayer were a good part of the game, there are many game modes to choose from capture the flag, frontline attack and defense even the skirmish cooperative mode. But all of the multiplayer feature has been disabled since GameSpy has been shutdown.Men of War: Assault Squad is yet to be the best of Men of War series. Many features and addition makes the game more rich with content to play with in the editor. I recommend this.Rating 8/10

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Who ever said war was easy? I totally recommend this game! This is one of the greatest WW2 RTS's on Steam! Men of War: Assault Squad is really hard and this adds a level of action and excitement. It adds fine control of your squads to the unit. You can directly control them where it's kinda like a shooter of some sort, or you can control them like traditional RTS. You can also manage their inventories. Did your tank blow up? No problem, just don't forget to take the MG! I recommend this game over any other WW2 game even Call of Duty: World At War or Company of Heroes. What I especially love in this game are the tanks! Who doesn't love tanks! The tanks in this game are so amazing! Tanks don't just blow up if the health reachs 0; there are multiple ways to disable a tank. Driving a tank gives you really false confidence because in the open, it is vulnerable to attack either by AT guns or bigger and better tanks.  One time, one of my tanks got stuck on a bridge and just tumbled off and ruined the engine. It was a bit annoying yet cool at the same time. Every unit in the game has a role and the combination of these units really helps your battalion/company/whatever. For instance, you can have a sniper supress the enemy while you move your infantry forward to attack. It's never that simple though!This game is really worth the money, get the second if you wish! I haven't tried the second but I will after I finish the Skirmish mode (Campaign).

content:
Posted: April 11
												Just skip it entirely & move on to Men of War Assault Squad 2 which is better in every way.Now, that being said, MoW:AS is on a league of its own from strategical & tactical point of view. Mesh it up with the game's forte - "realism", and you get a rts where you actually have to really really use your brain. Boi, no room for blobbing!It's chaotic, brutal. unforgiving; make a mistake & death awaits. Micromanagment is the heart of the game, which may very well be a double edged sword. It's certainly a strong suit but can easily become overwhelming & convoluted for some.Now, the reason why I don't recommend this game is because how the singleplayer feels so bland & lackluster. Same mission objectives for every factions make it repititive; offers no variation. Surely, you can complete each mission in different ways but it gets boring nonetheless.Also, the unit control is pretty sloppy & the A.I. pathing is absolutely horrendous. Frequent crash just made me hate the game more!TL;DR: You have MoW:AS2. So, why need this one?

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												50% of the time you troops will jog through enemy fire without so much as raising their weapons. This is not sprint, this is just really dumb AI. And god, the AI in this game are so terrible. Easy=godlike soldiers vs enemy army of developmentally delayed people. Hard=an army of paper dolls vs an army of Jedi with tanks and machineguns. Enemy vehicles on all difficulty levels are OP as ♥♥♥♥. A jeep (which has no protection at all, it can be destroyed by MGs and has no sides) can easily slaughter a squad of panzergrenadiers. The player's AI will not throw grenades back or duck out of the way. The enemy AI will use every grenade you throw at them to throw back and kill your troops. Player AI will not use antitank grenades on tanks, instead they will use it on a single enemy unit running across their line of sight, instead of using the fully-loaded MP44 in their hands. There is no campaign, just skirmish missions with the same 20 or so units for each faction and the same 2 support options. This game was made for multiplayer only and yet it has no multiplayer. It also HAS NO GEM EDITOR.TL;DR AI is broken, little content, do not buy

content:
Posted: March 22
												This is a strategy game that doesn't seem to know what level of operational command the player is supposed to be simulating.  In theory, you are in charge of a combined arms force at roughly the company level.  Or thereabouts.  In practice, you are a Corporal who is on babysitting duty.  I am not the first person to say that there is a lot of micromanaging in this game.  However, I will point out that this game does not have a very good micromanaging interface.  I still don't know how to refuel a tank with a supply truck.  Yes, your tanks have finite fuel.  This sounds cool.  In reality, they run out after about two or so minutes of movement.  Then you have to refuel them.  Somehow.  The game doesn't say (not even in the Tutorial) and the answer is not obvious at first glance.  And I don't feel I should have to look up the solution to a basic game mechanic that wasn't necessary in the first place.  If you want refueling, make a game on a higher level of strategy and on a longer timescale.The needless micromanaging goes even further than that, however.  If your men become wounded and are bleeding out, you have to order a medic in the squad to revive them.  Honestly, what's the point of having a medic if they don't heal your nearby wounded on their own?  Of course, the medic is a standard combatant otherwise.  So, congratulations, you're a war criminal, even if you're playing the Commonwealth or US.  This is bad enought, but to make matters worse the medics are not even clearly marked at a glance.  In fact, they are quite difficult to find in a squad.  You have to click on squad members or zoom in to ground level to find the medic, then select them, then order them to do their job.  And that's assuming the medic didn't die.  Maybe they did and you forgot.  You've got so much on your plate in would certainly be easy to not notice one dead soldier amongst the carnage.  If you do notice the medic is dead, or bleeding out himself, then you have to use the above mentioned item trading interface, in all it's clunky glory, to have another man search the medic, take his medical bag, and then revive the medic.  You can give the medic his bag back.  Or you can let the other soldier keep it and act as medic from that point on.  It makes no difference in terms of performance.Of course, all this micromanaging to refuel, heal, and wipe after a bowel movement is just there to distract the player from just how awful the game is otherwise.  Ignoring various bugs and texture issues, the fact is that tanks are incredibly fragile.  At least against the heavier AT guns.  That only the computer gets.  The player has to make due with medium AT guns.  Which tend to not get the job done.  In effect, this makes your tanks completely worthless and the AI tanks rather sturdy.  This is a bit of a major point because the AI has AT guns and the like in large numbers.  In theory, you can amass a large number of tanks and push through, spearhead style, but that will take forever.  Tanks are expensive and are mostly there for infantry support.  To more effectively use them, the player must first neutralize the enemy AT defenses, which often involves just taking the capture point outright.  As such, your tanks are mostly just mobile AT guns that are brought up after taking a capture point to beat back the one or two tanks that are sent to retake it.  Infantry are also somewhat fragile, but at least you get a lot of them.Speaking of AT guns everywhere, every level is the same more or less.  Each skirmish map is designed with the same basic idea.  You start in a position, and have to capture ten enemy capture points.  These are always divided into three lines of defense.  The first only has infantry hiding behind some basic cover (sandbags, usually).  The second level of defense has infantry and basic AT guns.  Honestly, not too bad all things considered.  Then you reach the third level of defense.  Heavy AT guns and the like (the Americans usually have to face a lot of Flak 88s which aren't technically AT guns) are EVERYWHERE.  And near the final capture points, tucked in the back, are two Artillery pieces.  These range from  heavy howitzers, to rocket artillery platforms.  There are always two of them.  They "cover" the 3rd line of defense and protect the final capture points.  They are annoying.  The best way to defeat them is to use your faction's special ability.  Except for the Germans.  The Goliath is a joke.  Get ready to take a lot of casualties for Deutschland because the idiots who made this game decided to be cute and overly gimmicky.  There, I just described every skirmish map in the whole game.  Some of these maps are better than others (I actually kind of liked the "Gibraltar of the East" map for the Japanese) but all fit the description above.  All of them.I suppose I should elaborate on why the Germans got screwed by bad game design.  You see the Goliath is... a tiny RC tank that has an admittedly powerful bomb in it.  This bomb also has an incendiary effect which kills infantry very effectively.  This sounds good.  Until you realize that the Goliath "ability" is otherwise a unit and has to get to the enemy position before you can detonate it.  Which means getting through the AT guns and Artillery that are your target.  Pray the Goliath isn't destroyed near your men, or its bomb will end up hurting you and not the enemy.  This is a constant concern.  Especially given how annoyingly accurate the enemy guns are.  Even on Easy mode.  And the worse part is that the Goliath's bomb has the same basic payload as the American Airstrike, the British Artillery Bombardments, and a single round from the Soviet's special unit (I forget the name) which is just a really big piece of Artillery.  The Japanese special unit, two pieces of Type 100 Rocket Artillery are also roughly comparable in overall damage.  Except all of those get to deliver their payload across the entire map (or a long way across the map for the Type 100 and Soviet Super Gun) automatically.  The Goliath has to be carefully piloted across the map by the player.  Yes, more micromanaging.  In a game that already has too much micromanaging and most of it already unnecessary to begin with.  I get the Nazis were bad, but if you're going to make them playable, don't take it out on the player.Bottom line:  This game is terrible, lacks any real depth, make bizarre balancing decisions (see Goliath) that are also terrible.  The developers put up a smokescreen of micromanaging to distract the player from this reality, but the micromanaging ends up being a terrible reality in its own right.  A failure of shallow design covered up by a failure of overly detailed executions.  The Yin and Yang of bad game design together in one rancid package.  Buy this game at your own peril.  And be very wary of the sequel.  I imagine they haven't changed too much, though I admittedly don't know because this debut has scared me away from the entire franchise.

Posted: December 13, 2014
												Men of War: Assault Squad is a World War 2 real time strategy game. I have logged over 100 hours on this game and I would like to say that I have had a pleasant experience with this game. I will admit, there are some slightly broken aspects of this game. Things like American Shotgun Troopers, some of the tanks *cough cough* Germany *cough cough*, and artillery in general. But overall, I have had a pleasant experience playing this games with friends. Speaking of which, the multiplayer of this game is somewhat shut down since it was formerly ran via GameSpy. There are several ways to combat this problem, but I used the Direct Connect method. This is where you and a friend(s) exchange IP's, add them to your multiplayer options, and then go to LAN. If you did this correctly, you should see each other in the lobby. To recap, it's a good game. Just be careful. 9/10

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												This game has a mod called "Dynamic campaign generator".This mod adds completely different dimension to the game as it will let You build Your force from the begining of hostilities and follow the war till the end of it on all fronts. Troops will acquire experience and their equipment will follow from one battle to the next (unless You choose to reset their invetories). My recomendations for a german side starting 1940 - bring Your 88 guns ASAP and capture as many Bren Carriers as You can. You can store a lot of equipment in those carriers. This will let You keep micromanagement to the minimum as "reset all inventories" will not reset captured vehicles yet You will not be forced to micromanage every soldier and every gun as they will have their munitions in each battle. There is no way to resuplay Your own tanks in the mod, for example, unless You reset their inventories.  And those carriers are superb for towing Your 88 flak guns around the battlefield - they have rather low profile and will let flak guns to fire over the carrier and they will provide a good MG cover against attacking infantry.I hope the creators of this awesome mod will continue with Assault Squad 2 and add more features in the future also.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Well, everyone round here knows I love (or rather love/hate thanks to the many bugs) all of the Men of War series - and Faces of War. "Assault Squad" is no different. But I have to declare that gameplay wise, this one is the weakest of the series, yet technically it's one of the most sturdy and bug free (don't worry, many old favourite bugs even from FoW's day are *still* hanging in there)! The opposite to "Condemed Heroes" and "Red Tide" which had the best gameplay, interesting story and well designed missions, but teeming with bugs!One simple reason for the low gameplay score..... the most lazy, half-arsed scenario design I have ever seen!ALL 5 campaigns for each nation are just literally cut & paste copies of each other..... getting all the DLCs for MOW:AS is also a must - when they're on a good offer that is! They at least introduce a few new types of scenarios - including a special "Xmas" one!The other fault, and evidence of lazy programming, is the "sod doing any more work than needed, let's just give the AI infinite respawns and infinate RPs" attitude. This makes for some very long winded, exhausting scenarios - which you will have to play on permanent slo-mo mode just in order to keep up!The game is heavily biased toward LAN/Internet play and people who will build their own scenarios.There are no "script heavy storyline" missions like in the other MoWs!Taken on their own individual merits, these skirmish style are OK, but the repitition gets very, very old, very, very quick! Being a stubborn smacktard, I still went and worked through them all!"1C" still have not been bothered to supply proper AI bots that can be used in LAN/Internet play. They've left that for Assault Squad 2, as a STUPIDLY overpriced DLC - which many report doesn't even work. What next, "Pause Mode DLC" for £19.99? Better not give "1C" any ideas - it's looking like they are all turning into David "Robber" Brabens!The best thing is, the modding community! There's tons of mods available, you are far from stuck with "1C"'s repetitive scenarios!

												If Company of Heroes and Blitzkrieg made a baby, this is what you get. At first I loved the baby, but then I wanted to punt it, mostly because of the terribly frustrating enemy snipers! Here they are picking off my perfect defenses, and there isn't jack sh*t I could do about it. I would spend so much time just trying to find them, and by the time I would, half my troops would be a pile of splattered brains on the ground. So I left the game for a few days, thought about it, and then realized I was moving too slowly. Make sure you grab those resources quick and early, and maybe you'll have enough to survive when bad things happen! So, I just finished playing a Commonwealth Mission, Operation Torch on hard. No idea how long it took, but it was the craziest slug fest ever. At the ramps there was a stalemate for hours. The dead tanks meant I couldn't rush with armor, and their constant sniper attacks were keeping my men from advancing. Finally the key...tons of antitank guns, lots of my own snipers, supported by infantry, and the occasional morter. Final casualty count - Germany Casualties = 7445men and 439 vehicles. Commonwealth Casualties = 2511 men and 164 vehicles. I $#!@#%@# love this game!!! P.S. Anyone know how best to push dead tanks out of your way?

content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Underatted but incredible.Picked this game up in the humble-bundle and conviced some friends to do it too... Had massive fun destroying them in 1v1/2v2/3v3/4v4 matches (each one seems like a completely different experience) as well as being destroyed by them and teaming up with them to fight against AI and progress through the map whilst getting rewards along the way.Looking forward to pick up Men of War: Assault Squad 2 as well as Call to Arms at some point too!Only downsides are that there is no obvious 'Free for All' type which means you need to have an even number of players for it to be a fair game (each player gets 100CP to spend on units, meaning the larger team always has an extra 100 to spend) as well as the fact that the system that was used for multiplayer having been shut down (the only ways to play multiplayer are throuh programs such as Hamachi, Gameranger, Tunngle or by just using LAN if you're on the same network).I would reccomend getting this game definitely, but if you have the money to spare then Men of War: Assault Squad 2 or even Call to Arms (although it's early access) may be a better option due to more features as well as a more expansive multiplayer system which will also allow you to fight with/against random players and not just your friends or people you know.Performance is a little iffy in terms of seemingly having fps that is dependant on how many units are on the field no matter what your PC's specs are (many units = lag, especially tanks or other vehicles)If I had to rate it out of 10 I would give it an 8/10, it's a great game but has a few flaws which are seemingly solved in the sequel.There are few games that I've had as much fun playing with friends than this.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												It's not that this is a <bad> game, it's just so unbelievably frustrating it's not worth your time. Your unit AI will need micromanaging down to the ammo they need to shoot guns. They are too stupid to pick up ammo from bodies automatically. If someone runs out of ammo they stand still and wait to die. Pathfinding is completly broken. For example: A squad needs to get into a trench, instead of jumping into the trench from the side they are closest to, they will run all the way around to the far end of the trench will there is a proper ramp, usually resulting in the entire squad getting gunned down. Medics need your guidance to heal thier mates. They will wait next to someone bleeding out, unless you take the time to select the medic and click on the downed guy the medic will not heal him. Tank movement needs constant micromanagement as well. If you want a tank to back up, it will decide on its own to do a 180 and expose it's♥♥♥♥♥to enemy fire.There is no story mode, the single player "skirmishes" are based on battles from history and (all the achevements are from singleplayer btw) are very cookie cutter, you start with one unit and take objective capture points one by one to unlock more tanks that can be called in as reinforcements.  Every skirmish mission is like this. Skirmish difficulty scales way to high very quickly. Your tanks often get oneshotted by seemingly inferior enemy tanks. Advancing with your tank is suicide as enemy AT guns are impossible to take out before your tanks are one shotted. Your AT guns? Usually goes like this: MISSMISSBOUNCEMISSGLANCING HITIf you decide to play this game kep the asprin close. And stretch your thumb and index finger for the ineviatble ALT-F4

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												NOTE: Normal MP for this game will have gone down when the Gamespy servers go down, but you can still play MP through GameRanger, or LAN. Hamachi works too, for obvious reasons. This is an amazing game, a strategy gem like none before it (except the other MoW games). Put your units into one man teams and micromanage their positions, or put them in huge squads and let them do it themselves. Take direct control over a unit and use it to provide accurate fire, be it with rifle, MG, tank canon or heavy artillery. You can be anyone, tell your men to do anything.The singleplayer is fun, albeit extremely hard and there is no dynamic 'hop in and play a random battle' mode, such as games like CoH have. The 'Skirmish' mode is really just three (or five with DLC), where you push forward and capture points, which allows you to call in new units to use on the unrelentingly hard enemy. Once you finally beat a level, you are awarded with the next, even harder level to defeat. The difficulty can be annoying and extremely frustrating but it finally beating it feels great.Overall, this is one of the greatest strategy games I've played, and while steam hasn't tracked many of my hours on it, I have a lot more than is shown. Improves upon the shortcomings of past games, and while opting for a more MP-focused format still makes SP fun. 8/10

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												I have played all the MoW games prior to this one, and I recommend them all.  The MoW brand of military RTS is absolutely amazing... the emphasis is definitely on realism... with actual penetration and armor values, unit inventory, destructable environs, and limited resources.  The day I realized that I could loot a dead enemy's body for weapons, health kits, and rounds made me a believer.As such, MoW:AS is basically the same gameplay, with the exception that there is no "campaign" with a scripted overarching story.  Missions are skirmishes against the computer AI (some with limited scripting) and multiplayer human vs. human on a number of maps and using several different game modes.  Initial resources are granted as "points" which can be spent to buy units.  Additional points slowly trickle in... as capture points are seized additional advanced units become available for purchase.  Reinforcements appear at the bottom of the map and advance to the point you designate.I have played the skirmish modes for a number of hours now on easy, which is still challenging.  There are many factions... german, american, british, japanese... some good map variety and about 20-25 skirmish missions will keep you busy for about 30 hours.  The more advanced maps are very challenging and usually involve multiple phases.I only have a few complaints about this game:> It should be easier to re-supply troops with ammo from fallen enemy soldiers, or the resupply truck.  Automating that task would be a huge improvement.> Some maps feel repetitive... a few more scripts to add variety would be welcomeRelatively minor annoyances honestly.  If you are a WWII RTS fan, then get this game immediately.  Even better, start with the original MoW and play the rest of them first.  You will learn all the commands and gameplay tricks.  If you are a Company of Heroes fan, give this a try for a much more interersting challenge.8/10

												One of my favorite games of all time. If you don't care for multiplayer, I would really recommend getting this over CtA and even MoW:AS2. The few added features, while very cool, are not worth the price.This game has a ton of great things about it. An awesome editor, great game mechanics, destructable buildings, a detailed inventory system, and a vast array of gameplay options.You can repair and take over broken enemy vehicles, take ammo from both friendly and dead enemy soldiers, plant dynamite and mines, change out helmets, and a ton of other interesting things.Be warned that this game has a lot of micromanagement, but with that micromanagement comes a lot of depth.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I am going to have to thumbs up on this game. The game itself is certainly a fun one; gets the brain working for strategy, and is rather realistic on its approach to a WWII RTS. To me it's like if Red Orchestra was turned into an RTS.The only thing that kills this game (and not the fault of the game or the devs) is the community. It's fairly difficult to find a friendly random to play with. If you don't have high levels, you will certainly get kicked from a few games before finally finding one, and some of the high-level players are completely dishonorable by choosing to fight weaker new players rather than those of their own callibre. There is also no random matchmaking, so you HAVE to find an accepting server if you want to play (and multiplayer is the core of this game)Basically, great game, but I would suggest encouraging a personal friend to also get the game, or gift a copy to him or her as well. This game is REALLY fun if you got fun people to play with.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												This is a very nice game, with nicely-flowing campaigns for every major nation in the war. The detail of combat is amazing, and reminds me a bit of my old Gamecube game, Battalion Wars, where you can take control of the most modest infantryman, or that badass battlestation (or in this game, the Tiger tank) and go to town with it.It's the first game I've seen in awhile that accuratly show how vulnerable tanks actually were. In most games, they're these killing machines that somehow take multiple shells, but here, with this game's tank armor system, almost anything can knock out a tank without actually destroying it, such a mine taking out a tread to render it immobile, or a well-placed shot that snaps the barrel of the main gun, or of course just blowing the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it.This game also has a fully destructable map, where you can knock down a small wall, an apartment building, or even put ♥♥♥♥ing holes in the ground from motar and artillery shells.It alas doesn't well represent the mortality of man, where they are able to somehow take an 8,8cm Tiger shell straight to the face.But all-in-all, this is a very fine game and it's a great pick for a dual WWII/RTS intrest.---German Soldiers Mod Review---I really love this mod, it adds even more realism (like the mortality of man) and is generally just really freaking awesome. I especially love that it adds Westerwald Lied to the main menu's music.<3 German Marches

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												TL:DR, If you enjoy realistic games, and you enjoy RTS games, this is great even if you pay full priceFirst off, if you played earlier men of wars and found the to be overly difficult and annoying, this fixes problems. I remember playing MoW Vietnam. The final kill counts were like me 600 kills, them 6. This game is NOT like that. They allow for a lot more renforcements which creates bigger and better battles.If you have never played, Imagine Company of Heroes but way more realistic. Every unit has an inventory which can be scavanged and depleted. If you have a tank in battle for a prolonged ammount of time you may find your self out of HE, AP, or the covited APCR(I will expand on ammo types and options in the next section). Machine guns can run black, and so can snipers. Every one is prone to running completely black on ammo. The cool thing is you can always scavange, many times in my American play I found myself picking up and MP40 when I felt like it may be more effective for the close range fighting that was happening. All weapons and all ammo drops when units die, and can be picked up, unless the unit is blown up. The game also allows you to buy a supply truck completely loaded with 1000s of rounds of ammo. Also each unit has many options as to weapons they can use, unlike CoH, you can actually have unit switch to a side arm, or switch to grenade, you have so much more control of each man on the field. Where this become most evident it with the armor, This game has some of the best tank physics I have ever seen, when you shoot something with an AP round, you can actually see the hole if it punctures, as well as it hits every on in its path just like a real AP round. It does not just blow up the tank, it blows a hole through it. That is if you actually get a clean hit with a big enough cannon. This is the best part of this game, tank on tank battles. I had a single Stuart take on anything the Jap army could send, That same tank was completly worthless against the germans. Super realistic and fun, and allows for complete control.My last point and best part about this game, is the direct control. If you just hit E on any unit it gives you complete control. You aim the weapon, fire it, and move with the WASD. Where as normally in an RTS you just right click to attack, in this you can move and attack, with the most possible control, especially with tanks. Moving into postion with a sherman and hitting a Panzer IV point blank with a 76mm APCR Is one of the coolest things you can do.From a game play standpoint, I got the whole thing on sale, with all the DLC. Which comes with 5 mission for each of the Russian, German, American, Japanese, and Common Wealth factions. Play slow and enjoying it took me 8 hours to beat the USA campagn. So a lot of paytime there. TONS of units!!Great fun, Cheap game, do it!

Posted: December 3, 2014
												Clunky, budgeted, and sometimes brutally unfair thanks to luck alone, Men of War: Assault Squad is still a rock-solid title with its own unique attributes that set it apart from Company of Heroes and other WW2 RTS titles.What Men of War does best is its keen focus on mimicking the reality of war. There is no such thing as a bottomless magazine, an unlimited fuel tank, or a tank with more rounds than potential targets. There is no be-all, end-all weapon to any situation and every engagement demands its own proportionate response. Wasting troops, ammunition, or even just the fuel in a vehicle can cripple that unit in engagements to come or complicate matters beyond reason.Did you use up all the high-explosive shells in a tank and now have to face off against dug-in infantry? Good luck trying to snipe them with armor-piercing rounds. Did you fire off all your mortars in a team and now have to destroy an anti-tank gun or lose one of your expensive armored vehicles? Have fun waiting for a new mortar team or supply truck while your tank takes fire it can't respond to.Range, lethality, and mobility all play crucial roles; tanks can fire far and wide across the map and receive attacks from field guns at even further distances. Vehicles can and will be destroyed in a single shot from a position far across the map or left crippled and useless by a strike to their treads, turret, or main gun. Critical anti-tank infantry or machine gunners can be shot out from under you by snipers, artillery, or even just an unlucky ricochet off of a tank's armor, all happening in the blink of an eye.Even as brutal as Men of War can be, there are often moments of forgiveness to take advantage of. Vehicles left unuseable are usually left abandoned in a state that can be salvaged. Though time-expensive, all infantry can repair a badly crippled, seemingly useless heavy tank back into fighting condition and crew it. A single rifleman with luck and determination can be used to repair and steal a damaged enemy tank right out from under their noses and bring it back to base to be fully crewed and put back to work. Most infantry fall injured rather than killed outright and swift management of a combat medic can bring decimated squads back into the fight with minimal losses. Valuable weapons can be scavenged, stolen, and re-supplied in the heat of battle by any unit, allowing a dismounted tank crew to become a formidable close quarters assault team when the right tools are left to take.A solid foundation of realism and hard-hitting micromanagement make Men of War a game worth playing, but it can often be questionable in its aesthetics department. Sometimes bizarre, universally short unit responses, average or above-average quality music with little dynamic manipulation, and a sound system that leaves much to be desired, even as much as the sounds themselves are of good quality, all contribute to an uneven audio experience. Animations that can range from goofy to floaty to eye-catchingly strange hold down its otherwise surprisingly good model quality.Overall, from my short experience in the game, Men of War is a series I wish I had gotten into sooner. Its short list of failings hardly dent what is, in the end, a game well worth its price tag. As a warning to all who consider purchasing it, I would like to note that, with GameSpy down, multiplayer may be difficult to get into or even impossible for those with problematic connections; services like GameRanger are required to do more than singleplayer, as my own experience tells me.

Posted: June 24, 2011
												On the surface, MoW:AA plays like an RTS set during the events of WWII. However, what sets the game apart is the ability to super-micro manage all units.  Each soldier has an inventory and skill level with weapons, tanks need to be crewed by multiple soldiers, etc.  Additionally, each unit can be "direct controlled", in an almost arcade like fashion.  Success involves the use of real  world tactics such as effective use of terrain, cover, suppressive fire, line of sight, correct deployment of troops, and basics of understanding the ballistic effectiveness of armor and anti-armor units in various scenarios.  The game really shines in co-op and supports as many as eight players cooperating against a devastatingly effective AI.  If you ever pick it up, look me up for a game!

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Brilliant game. It's realistic as can be and fun as hell.You can lob a grenade through the roof of a Greyhound and decrew it like a boss.You can ambush Nazi pigs like a boss.You can storm the beaches of Normandy like a boss.ORYou can just ♥♥♥♥ing obliterate everything with scorched earth tactics and ♥♥♥♥ing level entire cities like a boss.Hardest ♥♥♥♥ing RTS of life, But by far one of the most badass series' ive ever played.The ONE THING that gets to me (I've just gotta ♥♥♥♥♥ about this) Is how easily you can lose high value units. You can spend 1000cp on a Veteran Tiger and roll it on up just to have it get detracked by invisible commies throwing homing AT grenades. THEN BC HEAVY TANKS ARE SLOW they can just keep lobbing at grenades and ♥♥♥♥ your♥♥♥♥♥♥up.Flak 88's can destroy anything in one shot (Unless you're the luckiest SOB ever).AT Guns are very easy to decrew but if cared for you can win with just AT guns and infantry.Infantry goes hard. The MEN of Men of War are the key and by far the best part. It's almost like you're watching a real war. Finally, the GEM Editor is fantastic. If you like this game check out the Cold War mod (v1.5.7) and take it into the editor. It's a much better game with everything from M1A2's and Apache's to BTR-90's and T-90's to play with.Fantastically done. 10/10

												Clunky, budgeted, and sometimes brutally unfair thanks to luck alone, Men of War: Assault Squad is still a rock-solid title with its own unique attributes that set it apart from Company of Heroes and other WW2 RTS titles.What Men of War does best is its keen focus on mimicking the reality of war. There is no such thing as a bottomless magazine, an unlimited fuel tank, or a tank with more rounds than potential targets. There is no be-all, end-all weapon to any situation and every engagement demands its own proportionate response. Wasting troops, ammunition, or even just the fuel in a vehicle can cripple that unit in engagements to come or complicate matters beyond reason.Did you use up all the high-explosive shells in a tank and now have to face off against dug-in infantry? Good luck trying to snipe them with armor-piercing rounds. Did you fire off all your mortars in a team and now have to destroy an anti-tank gun or lose one of your expensive armored vehicles? Have fun waiting for a new mortar team or supply truck while your tank takes fire it can't respond to.Range, lethality, and mobility all play crucial roles; tanks can fire far and wide across the map and receive attacks from field guns at even further distances. Vehicles can and will be destroyed in a single shot from a position far across the map or left crippled and useless by a strike to their treads, turret, or main gun. Critical anti-tank infantry or machine gunners can be shot out from under you by snipers, artillery, or even just an unlucky ricochet off of a tank's armor, all happening in the blink of an eye.Even as brutal as Men of War can be, there are often moments of forgiveness to take advantage of. Vehicles left unuseable are usually left abandoned in a state that can be salvaged. Though time-expensive, all infantry can repair a badly crippled, seemingly useless heavy tank back into fighting condition and crew it. A single rifleman with luck and determination can be used to repair and steal a damaged enemy tank right out from under their noses and bring it back to base to be fully crewed and put back to work. Most infantry fall injured rather than killed outright and swift management of a combat medic can bring decimated squads back into the fight with minimal losses. Valuable weapons can be scavenged, stolen, and re-supplied in the heat of battle by any unit, allowing a dismounted tank crew to become a formidable close quarters assault team when the right tools are left to take.A solid foundation of realism and hard-hitting micromanagement make Men of War a game worth playing, but it can often be questionable in its aesthetics department. Sometimes bizarre, universally short unit responses, average or above-average quality music with little dynamic manipulation, and a sound system that leaves much to be desired, even as much as the sounds themselves are of good quality, all contribute to an uneven audio experience. Animations that can range from goofy to floaty to eye-catchingly strange hold down its otherwise surprisingly good model quality.Overall, from my short experience in the game, Men of War is a series I wish I had gotten into sooner. Its short list of failings hardly dent what is, in the end, a game well worth its price tag. As a warning to all who consider purchasing it, I would like to note that, with GameSpy down, multiplayer may be difficult to get into or even impossible for those with problematic connections; services like GameRanger are required to do more than singleplayer, as my own experience tells me.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												I would give this game 9/10, but it's difficult. Like really difficult. Hell, I'm not able to do first mission even on easy mode, after I capture first 3, the enemy sends in endless waves of soldiers and armoured vehicles, and I'm not able to hold it on my own. Also, the first mission for every country IS THE SAME. Capture about 9-10 checkpoints, then proceed to next misson. I've bad feeling next missions are gonna be the same.You can use enemy weapons for your soldiers, you can pick up helmets, carefully pick off enemies with sniper, but not really, because at most times, the enemy turns full ape♥♥♥♥♥♥after you complete several checkpoints in missions, so there's no time to do such things. If your tank(s) get destroyed, your crew jumps out, which is nice, since you can use them not only to repair your tanks, but to repair enemy tanks and use them. But then again, not really, enemy won't give you chance to do it.This game is just difficult for me, I don't know why. I can't do more than 2 things at the same time, control several units at the same time, but enemy can, ofc. Easy difficulty feels difficult, but you can't go lower. If you're good at these games, you're gonna absolutely love it. Graphics aren't bad, pretty good for this game if you ask me. If only there was AI help for every mission, just like in introduction, it would be so much better.I can't really give this game anything, since I haven't done even the first mission on any country and I'm not really gonna play this game any longer due to personal probs, but so far, 7.5/10.I mean, repair enemy stuff and use it against him? Hell yeah!

Sometimes you can tell that about a game very quickly. Men of War feels really user-friendly and fun-friendly. In this tactical 3rd person strategy/shooter you can pause the game, slow it down, speed it up, take personal control of individual soldiers or command the squad. You can use a whole array of tactics and units. You can basically do whatever the hell you want to achieve the goal. The only probelm for me so far is lack of custom scenario mode, but there are custom missions and mods that fix that issue.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2011
												Men of War Assault Squad is a game that put you in charge of the chaos of war in a wide diversity of missions, environement and factions.Assault Squad offer 16 skirmish missions that can be define as a struggle against wave after wave of enemies who are not only attacking you but are well entrenched to stop your advance.To achieve victory you will have to essentially tactically fight, destroy, blow up, fix deploy a largy diversity of equipement this game contain. The result give you an intense firefight that establish a delicate balance between the two side. You can go from a dominating position to losing all your tanks. This mean a skirmish mission can take you from 30 min to many days depending the difficulty.Now if that wasn't enough, the multiplayer adverserially allow you to test your tactical skill against other people in a huge diversity of map.To conclude this is certainly one of the best RTS released in a long time.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												I absolutely love this game. If you like RTS or RTT, games like World in Conflict or Command and Conquer this is a good game to get. The game has amazing vehical and infantry combat, awesome graphics and a massive varity of units, vehicals, and weapons. The game is pretty realstic and has a lot of depth to it. Yeah, the voice acting is a little "meh" but it doesn't take away from the amazing experiance the game offers. You can double or even triple your amount of fun with mods for example, the Fields of Honor, Star Gate, World War 1, and Cold War mods. If you like real time strategy or real time tatics games this is good choice. If your like World War 2 strategy games this is a good choice. If you are bored of all your current strategy games and are looking for a new one, this is a good game to try out.*EDIT* MOST IMPORTANT NOTE: Recently Men of War Assault Squad 1's multiplayer has been shut down due to Gamespy closeing. Instead of switiching providers like other games did (for example Arma 2) the owner of the Men of War franchise decided to only switch Men of War Assault Squad 2's multiplayer provider. Thus, forceing fans to buy Men of War Assault Squad 2, which is a horrible game. So the only way to play multiplayer on Men of War Assault Squad 1 now is to use Gameranger. It is still a great game but without knowing how to use gameranger and haveing some friends, it looses what makes it so unique. And, since Men of War Assault Squad 2 is litteraly, a piece of crap cranked to keep up with Company of Heroes, Men of War's rival. All in all, MOWAS 1 is a solid good game but has no multiplayer.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Ever wanted to fight a war, more so a World War that too in real time,than this is your game.It is an absolute mammoth of a game.Men of war assault squad is not for the faint of heart, so weak of heart read it  at your own risk. Men of war assault squad is a game well crafted ,to suit the need of any five years old ,who ever wanted to or did or does play with toy soldiers.The game has more than one campaigns and you can play in the skirmish mode as any of the allied nations,the common wealth even Germany.You start off each game with a basic squad and as you progress through, you have to capture enemy flag points to gain more troops or bonuses.There is smooth progression through levels as you capture each check point.At first generally light vehicles are allowed,at the next point you get your hands on heavier automobile troops.Than gradually bombers and even ship bombardments.One thing that is going to attract any tactician is the fact that as you play as various factions you have to face different terrain types like tundra,farms,cities,towns,desert, and in each you have to adapt to a different form of war fare.In some snipers may rule the roost, in others heavy tanks and infantry.Likewise you have at your disposal every ww2 unit type, that was ever used in this war in the game.There are realistic commands you can give to your units like suppress fire,fire machine gun,heal a unit,or drive a car.Which adds an aura of realism.As you play through various factions, you are deigned to face various battlefields which they faced in the war.There are typically nine flagpoints to capture, to win a level or a battlefield and each checkpoint is vital for even leaving one out can force you not to win the battle and proceed to the next level.The game is atmospheric for as you play you face different types of conditions in which to not just keep fighting but to survive with the forces at your disposal.There are many pros to this brilliant game--------------------------------PROS------------------------------+ You get hands on experience of the war fought eons ago at the touch of a mouse + You get it at a pocket friendly rate+ You get to experience what it was like commanding troops in the war+ realistic damage+ You get to change history as in the way battles were fought within a rigid storyline frame work--------------------------------CONS------------------------------Cant think of any and the game deserves its popularity but notabily there are two- No morale for infantry units - graphics are a bit out of dateAll in all a complete game,7/10 .Its definitely worth the buy specially at such low prices and more so for people who like to play with or have played in their childhood with toy soldiers attempting not just to recreate history but to relive it.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												This is basically Squad Micromanagement: The Game - World War II Edition.Player AI is brutally stupid and requires constant attention to stop your own soldiers from killing themselves. Visual indicators for FOV of the soldiers is nonexistent and the cover system is non-intuitive and unreliable.I tried to like this game. Three separate occasions, I started up the game and slogged through the tutorial and first mission, trying to figure out what I was doing wrong. Nope! You really DO have to manage each soldier's inventory during combat to find bandages to heal a wounded squadmate who is bleeding out while under fire! It's not NEARLY as fun as it sounds, believe me.If you look at screenshots of this game without actually playing it, it looks promising. Tons of weapons and items, vehicles. a cover system, everything you would want in a WWII squad command game, right? Then you try playing it, and it feels like a chore. If your game feels like a chore, theres probably something wrong with your game.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This is a RTS very similar to Company of Heroes and Dawn of War. However, each soldier has an idividual inventory, requires ammo, has weapon proficiency levels that affect accuracy, can lose his rifle from shock, etc. Every little detail of war is thought of, such as scavenging dead bodies for ammo and a new helmet. Also, there is tons of mods available for this game that add plenty of new units and options. Another great touch is this game includes a built in editor that allows you to build custom maps and battles. All in all, MOW is a hidden gem among RTS games and is a great for those interested in WW2.If you are a fan of RTS games, you can't go wrong with Men of War Assault Squad!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2012
												Coming from someone who was a big fan of Relic COH and Warhammer series, this is definitely way better. Pro:Amazing detail and realism. All ballistics are modelled physically. There is no life bar on tanks instead it depends of physics and penetration, any parts that are damaged will result different effect. A lot of different tactics to try out.Environments are very detailed and battlefield changes dynamically, building can be destoryed, wreckage block tank's path and create new cover etc. No two game played out the same way.For me it's a pro, there's a lot of micro management down to the manually manage ammunition of each individual soldier and gas up vehicles manually. Some player might not like this though.---Con: Graphics are functional, but nothing to write home about. Audio gets repetitive after a while, all units repeat the same lines to acknownlege your commands.The game is very unforgiving, be prepared to save an reload a lot. Even the best tank can be one-shot killed if you are not careful. Sometime feels like a puzzle game where you are carefully removing enemies' defence one piece at a time. At the writing of this review only 8.4% of players completed the first mission on normal difficulty, so don't be shy to start out in easy difficulty.No stories to speak of, just go from south part of the map to the north that's about it. If you want story you should try other MOW titles.The game model the ballistic of every bullets, so you need a good CPU, instead of GPUs like other games. Even on my i7 3770 the game can slow down in very large battles. Not game breaking but you should be aware of this if you have older machines.---Conclusion, Hardest RTS I've ever played, period. It is so cruel... Anyone up to a real stiff challenge should try this. I'd give it 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												8.7/10Pros+5 playable nations+Large array of WWII era weapons, troops, vehicles, and equipment+Realistic feel in terms of damage, weapon accuracy, vehicle stats+Sort of doubles as a "Third Person Shooter" (You can directly control units individually)+Beautiful visuals+Extremely well designed maps+Tactical Multiplayer Cons-Very difficult at first-The voice acting is beyond bad-Offers only a few levels per nation -No mode where you can customize match settings and location-Vehicle AI can be dumb at timesThis is a game I really enjoyed. The allure, to me, is that they went in a different direction with the typical WWII genre. You have games like Company of Heroes where they play as an RTS. This game takes what COH does well, and expounds upon it. There isn't much of a story, not that you really need one, I mean, it is based in WWII and you fight in major battles. The style is very much like any other RTS, except that it doesn't have base building, and you can directly control each unit. This, combined with beautiful level design, realistic weapons/stats/damage, and intuitive game play, and you get a very well put together game.With that ut of the way, I do have a couple of critisisms that irked me the whole way through. First and foremost, This game only offers 3 missions per nation. That's right, 3 mission. More can be purchased through Steam, but it is disappointing to see that this game isn't very long when it comes to single player. It also bummed me out that it lacks any kind of match making verus AI, like COH, or any other RTS. I don't know if that was a technical limitation, or what, but it makes the game developers look lazy, which is a shame, because this game is so well put together. Something else you will find out is how hard this game is. You need to be slow and thoughtful in your approach to each objective, because enemies can out flank, or over power you if you aren't careful. This isn't nessecarily a bad thing, as it shows how well done the AI is in this game.And I forgot to mention how bad the narrator is. He has the same voice for all of the nations. It is laughable.Look, if you are like me, you buy games when they are on sale. This isn't a game you should pass off, but I wouldn't recommend buying it at full price. It is a load of fun, even though that fun is short-lived. And despite some replayability issues, it offers a multiplayer experience that will keep you in deep thought. Consider buying it if you enjoy a challenging, yet realistic experience.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												It's my firm belief that this is the most well-crafted RTS to date. The sheer amount of detail is staggering: Fully destructable environments and morphing landscape, fully realised unit inventories (guns, ammo, grenades, sandbags, explosives, knives, bandages; it's all there and freely tradeable between your soldiers), smart unit AI, direct control over any unit in the field, the best RTS cover system (brick walls actually stop bullets, as opposed to providing a 'defensive bonus') and realistic ballistics and damage models. Starcraft 2 looks like babbies first RTS by comparison.While good micro is still important, good macro, field awareness and tactical thinking play a more prominant role. Did Colonal T. Awesome get sniped while gunning down Fritz with his 50. cal? Then get Private S. Meatshield to go grab that machinegun, and do his mother proud. Your comms officer get blown up while trying to lay down an airstrike? Lay down some smoke and go grab his flaregun to finish the job!
