content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												If you like challenging RTS with a really steep learning curve, this is THE game for you. Do not get discouraged at first by it´s complexity and micromanagement intensive oriented gameplay. Once you grasp the basics and learn to play the game on, at the least, mediocre level, you will thoroughly enjoy it. I recommend you play it with a friend or somebody who can guide you through the initial stage. You wil get sweared upon for being a "noob", you will get kicked, thrashed and sometimes utterly crushed. The only way to overcome this is by learning the game and outplaying your opponents.Most of the community is rather unfriendly towards newcomers, therefore you should stick together with a friend. Even though and older release, you can get a game going fairly easily.If you are a casual gamer who prefers simple click-and-drag games and linear FPS shooters, stay away ! If you are a hardcore RTS fan who likes the challenge do not hesitate and buy this game at once. You will love it.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2012
												Coming from someone who was a big fan of Relic COH and Warhammer series, this is definitely way better. Pro:Amazing detail and realism. All ballistics are modelled physically. There is no life bar on tanks instead it depends of physics and penetration, any parts that are damaged will result different effect. A lot of different tactics to try out.Environments are very detailed and battlefield changes dynamically, building can be destoryed, wreckage block tank's path and create new cover etc. No two game played out the same way.For me it's a pro, there's a lot of micro management down to the manually manage ammunition of each individual soldier and gas up vehicles manually. Some player might not like this though.---Con: Graphics are functional, but nothing to write home about. Audio gets repetitive after a while, all units repeat the same lines to acknownlege your commands.The game is very unforgiving, be prepared to save an reload a lot. Even the best tank can be one-shot killed if you are not careful. Sometime feels like a puzzle game where you are carefully removing enemies' defence one piece at a time. At the writing of this review only 8.4% of players completed the first mission on normal difficulty, so don't be shy to start out in easy difficulty.No stories to speak of, just go from south part of the map to the north that's about it. If you want story you should try other MOW titles.The game model the ballistic of every bullets, so you need a good CPU, instead of GPUs like other games. Even on my i7 3770 the game can slow down in very large battles. Not game breaking but you should be aware of this if you have older machines.---Conclusion, Hardest RTS I've ever played, period. It is so cruel... Anyone up to a real stiff challenge should try this. I'd give it 8/10.

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												This is basically Squad Micromanagement: The Game - World War II Edition.Player AI is brutally stupid and requires constant attention to stop your own soldiers from killing themselves. Visual indicators for FOV of the soldiers is nonexistent and the cover system is non-intuitive and unreliable.I tried to like this game. Three separate occasions, I started up the game and slogged through the tutorial and first mission, trying to figure out what I was doing wrong. Nope! You really DO have to manage each soldier's inventory during combat to find bandages to heal a wounded squadmate who is bleeding out while under fire! It's not NEARLY as fun as it sounds, believe me.If you look at screenshots of this game without actually playing it, it looks promising. Tons of weapons and items, vehicles. a cover system, everything you would want in a WWII squad command game, right? Then you try playing it, and it feels like a chore. If your game feels like a chore, theres probably something wrong with your game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												This is a RTS very similar to Company of Heroes and Dawn of War. However, each soldier has an idividual inventory, requires ammo, has weapon proficiency levels that affect accuracy, can lose his rifle from shock, etc. Every little detail of war is thought of, such as scavenging dead bodies for ammo and a new helmet. Also, there is tons of mods available for this game that add plenty of new units and options. Another great touch is this game includes a built in editor that allows you to build custom maps and battles. All in all, MOW is a hidden gem among RTS games and is a great for those interested in WW2.If you are a fan of RTS games, you can't go wrong with Men of War Assault Squad!

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												This game was fun, hard, harder, then fun again. Don't play this game unless you are use to RTS games. I am not talking about Star Craft like games.This game will make you mad and make you happy when you beat a mission or destroy an opponent.I believe the online play is gone now as well. I played it a long time ago. My CD Key for the none Steam verison was not capable of being used on steam. And I ended up buying this game when it was on sale a year or two ago with its expansion packs. Wanted to play online, put in a log in and everything with the new CD Key from steam, was told my CD Key was used on another Email address. Called some people, looked up some stuff. Blah blah, was told I would have to pay 10$ for a new CD key. Never did. So, I quit playing this game. I also have some of the other MoW games. Same thing happen. So, I never played online with the Steam Verisons of MoW. Played through some of the Single Player. That got boring.But, Gamespy went out of buisness and the game stop being able to be played online unless you went through a 3rd party. So, I don't feel bad for not buying a new one. Just feel bad that I could not experience the game online as much as I wanted.But, like stated above, this game was fun, this game had great visuals. It required quick thinking, along with the ability to adabt and have loses without going crazy and destroying everything you have on a stupid move.Get this game, play it on Lan/IP with a friend. But, its going to get boring unless you go through a 3rd party to play with other people.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												I really like this game! It has graphics, destructive environments, and direct control, allowing you to take control of the IS-2 you just ordered in to the battlefield and destroy that enemy Panzer IV in a beautiful explosion while the building next to it crumbles down over it and it's supporting infantry.Objective variation is not good, not good at all. All the missions are: Take the battlefield... Also, some, or most maps end with the enemy throwing next to endless waves of tanks and infantry at your face... No "Blow that tank up" or "Destroy that building" objectives or anything like that. Not even secondary objectives! But if you have a good imagination you can issue yourself your own goals to follow. It's not neccesary, but it could keep you interested for a little longer. Of course not something like "Take that heavily defended Flak 88 within one minute" But i think you know what i mean. However, with all the nations: United Kingdom, USA, Germany, Japan, and Russia there are definately enough nation specific weapons and troops to keep you occupied for some time. Also, the variations from map to map and one the map are also quite good, for example the Overlord mission in the USA campain where you have to first, push up through a small village and then through open countryside, or the jungle in the first or second Japanese mission i don't remember the name of... And there's also a couple of mods i know that are worth trying out, like the "Unlimited popcap" for multiplayer, or Sirhinkels Skirmish maps for single play, or Cooperation. For something harder, that's more 'Trial and faliure' you could try the Carentan mod, which just adds one campaign, with one map. There's different ways to go to complete it though.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Its quite realistic and fun..the only annoying aspect is resupplying your troops is a hassle but while i haven't played 2 i'm told this issue was solved. and is some what 'auto' resupply there. but that doesn't effect this game.troops generally take cover and move realistically tanks aren't invincible if you have any form of anti tank..though tanks are actually quite vulnerable .-sends tank up to deal with a small group of infantry, unseen AT gun blows tank up- the multiplayer can be a bit annoying your forced to share "MP" which is military points used to purchase units. so playing with multiple people can become a hastle. it supports up to 8 players but i've only played with one other person. and its hard dividing it up between two people , let alone dividing it up 8 ways.the campaign doesn't have much in the way of a story its basically "a 5 second intro" and then it simply tells you to go from this objective to the next. theres no time limit in missions.and due to the realism and the somewhat direct manner of the maps -you can only usually advance forward its not usually possible to go around  the sides of the enemy -the game can be a little difficult and is quite time consuming . you can't save during Co-op(Skirmishes) .  but you can save in single player. for me battles usually took around 90 minutes.  but i'm the cautious try not to lose any soldiers type.difficulty levels of the game go from Easy, Normal, Hard, and Heroic.Heroic makes the game far more realistic soldiers rarely survive one shot.  lower difficulties they are more RTS like able to carry on for 5-10 hits.  the AI is a little unfair with its MP especially on heroic, you'll be rushed by NPC tanks long before you have the time to produce your own.Your units usually aren't very good at priortising targets and will some time require baby sitting if you don't want them to be murdered.Tanks often get confused an won't stay focused on the area you send them to. same with AT guns so often AI tanks will approach and your tanks will lose even if there in the perfect ambush positions. the units are detailed nicely. but the game to me is really fun. because i like planning and trying to work through the objectives.the DLC are pretty much the same scenario with the different nations. well..really most of the maps are the same battle/scenario just with the different nations themes. I recommend it if you like planning things out an don't mind spending an hour trying to accomplish objectives.

												Don't pass up the opportunity to get a free copy of Men of War with this. Get into the coop, you can do the single player missions with up to 3 other players and directly control any units, move and drive with the arrow keys and aim and shoot in full 3D with completely destructable maps. Insane amount of unique units a lot of which I have not seen before, use standard infantry to crew vehicles, complete inventory system, big attention to detail, real fog of war option and loads more.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2011
												This game is no Company of Heroes, frankly. There's a lot more micro-management and realism involved. Soldiers and guns run out of ammo, thus forcing you to go scavenge some. Tanks are more fragile than you'd expect, forcing you to keep an eye on them. Explosions will knock people out of vehicles, as seen when I missed a Jeep with a rocket and everybody inside of it flew out of the vehicle from the shockwave. Enemies will push you back if they think they can stop you at the right time. However, this is all worth it because it will give you a lot of crazy ♥♥♥♥ing stories to tell.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2011
												Following the announcement of the demise of Company of Heroes: Online set for 3-31-11, many fans, including myself, were caught off-guard and left searching for a replacement with as many similarities or even the possibility of something better to sink our bayonets into. Men of War: Assault Squads has this potential and already surpasses CoHO in a variety of ways. Even if you're still tooling around with vanilla CoH or any of the expansions and are tired of the hack monsters when attempting to engage in a simple multiplayer match, never fear, the developers seem to have those concerns in mind as well.Check out Youtube or elsewhere for some player made videos and see for yourself. If you're not a stranger to the MoW series, then think of this title as the polished and enhanced version of Men of War: everything you've been waiting for under one roof, so to speak. So, if you're a fan of WW2 RTS games, you won't be disappointed in the release of this well supported game. :-)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												IntroductionDue to my fascination of World War II era tanks I soon found on the internet a PC game which I thought would meet my taste for tank conquest.  Men of War: Assault Squad is a strategy/tactical game that takes place during World War II. The user is allowed to play just about nearly every faction, with each having its own uniqueness. Pros/ConsI first bought this game in the middle of July, with the purpose of finding a game more sided towards tank warfare. Having already logged 40 hours since purchasing, I consider myself an avid intermediate user. An Ideal user of this game would be someone who is fascinated with PC gaming and can handle a couple hours of sitting. While I wouldn’t recommend using the most basic computer available I did find it was supportive on most basic systems that are relatively new. My 3.5 star rating was comprised of three things:•	Difficulty•	Faction Uniqueness•	Tank IntegrationDifficulty – This game is very difficult to the new user. Perhaps almost too difficult if not on the right setting. It took me a couple hours just to get the mechanics of the game and how to play it effectively. Ultimately, though this is a challenge and as a dedicated gamer I can never say no to a challenge. Faction Uniqueness – This aspect of the game left me with my mouth open. Unlike most other games, every unit faction is somehow representative of its country in terms of performance and equipment. Especially with tanks I found this the greatest, as no two tanks were ever the same.Tank Integration – I was actually a bit saddened by this part. I initially was looking for a game that was more individualized to tank play. While tank play in this game is one of the most important keys, I found it to be a bit limiting with their use as the tanks are just one aspect of an army. Compounded with the micro control of every unit and the tanks seem a bit down played.ConclusionOverall I was pretty happy about my purchase of the game. Being a college student, I can’t afford a nice graphics card at this time, and found this game was able to meet my demands for gameplay and entertainment. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a challenging strategy war game.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Just gonna start out saying that I have put in far more time than it says on steam, and this used to be one of my favorite games. That has changed a lot now.The gameplay itself is lots of fun for me, but I am hating the game as a whole more every time I play. (keep in mind that I just play solo, with some rare co-op)AI is terrible. Infantry will take the dumbest routes to get to a location, and all the time i will lose armor because it decided to stare at a single enemy off to the side instead of watching the road that tanks were coming down.Balance is broken. Enemy armor and field guns seem to have much higher accuracy than mine. Also holy♥♥♥♥♥♥is it hard to kill things like enemy StuGs, but they can take mine out in one or two shots.And trying to get through Commonwealth missions is like trying to kick yourself in the head. Sure you can do it if you really try, but it's just going to hurt. They lack any usable anti-tank infantry and even their high cost vehicles can hardly take out the StuGs that they mainly go up against.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2011
												This game is no Company of Heroes, frankly. There's a lot more micro-management and realism involved. Soldiers and guns run out of ammo, thus forcing you to go scavenge some. Tanks are more fragile than you'd expect, forcing you to keep an eye on them. Explosions will knock people out of vehicles, as seen when I missed a Jeep with a rocket and everybody inside of it flew out of the vehicle from the shockwave. Enemies will push you back if they think they can stop you at the right time. However, this is all worth it because it will give you a lot of crazy ♥♥♥♥ing stories to tell.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												This game is truly an amazing RTS which features a butt tonne of stuff and thangs. I have owned this since early december 2014 and at first I thought it was not very special and it was pretty short due to the fact all factions just have 3 missions each which I still think is disappointing and the fact that you can get more missions for money I also find dissapointing but as soon as my friend said there is an editor for the game I suddenly could not stop playing it, I made alternate history campaigns for all the factions I liked and then it just got better with the mods; The UNIT mod and the cold war mods (1978 mod and the modern warfare one) are my recomended ones which are fantasitc, I do dislike the fact that there is a serious amount of mods that are the same for example ones which just give you the cold war or nukes or a reskin that gives people the face of Hitler and then the good mods are either dead or still not out. Nevertheless if you look you will find hella mods that you will love. all in all I give this a 9/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2011
												After a few years on the market this game had a rough start (Imo) with multiplayer tactics and balancing. Over time after a few patches, the game was pretty okay. Only reason im saying no now is because the multiplayer servers are taken offline and is no longer playable. The devs explained for some odd reason they cannot switch over to steamworks (So they make a copy-paste of assault squad with AS2 to get more money out of it instead of moving both games to steam servers). The games skirmish mode is alot of fun though if you want to kill some time. But I would wait till this game is $5-$10 because the multiplayer is what makes this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Men of War is already one of the most realistic war RTS's I've ever played, even more so than CoH, though if your more used to 'Health Bar' based things, you should just go play that instead, or SCII. From the beginning, when I realized I could do something as simple as throw my troops onto a tank's sides just as transport, I was enthralled. The tank combat in itself is pretty damn realistic! ( If you can account for near perfect shots from the enemy on hard mode every time... = w= )But from suppressive fire, to snipers in trees, to actual line of sight in MP... I think I've fallen in love~. Maybe you will too!V[-]X Signing out~!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												This game is probably worth the $10. But it's often on sale. If you like company of heroes, you'll like this. Major differences include the fact that you can take over movement and fire for individual units - which is fun. The other difference is that there are more unit options and seems to be a little more in-depth rather than streamlined. I'm not 100% sure on the historical accuracy but also seems more accurate. Nice destructible environments.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												The whole focus of Assault Squad is multiplayer and with the servers down there is literally no reason to buy this game. I don't mind a game with a good multiplayer but in this case this should be marketed as a multiplayer only game since the "campaign" is boring and tedious to get through and is not a campaign at all but a series of capture the victory point missions. In singleplayer, every faction has basicly the same exact units with different names, you have to capture victory points and win then go to another map that looks the exact same and repeat the process in a series of completely unrelated missions. I personally prefer every other men of war game to this one because they have a good singleplayer campaign.

content:
Posted: January 14
												I like this game, I recomend this game unless you can get men of war assult squad 2 (which I will refer to as mowas2 from now on). MoWAS1 is a very fun game and adds the WASD camera movement and right click to most things. The issue is with  MOWAS2 now out this game is obsolete. First off, since this game is very micromanagement orianted, which is not a bad thing in my opinion in this case, the old way of showing soldiers with big boxes on the bottom left doesen't really fit well. MoWAS2 is a newer game with update controls, graphics, and workshop combatibility. Although I like this game, with gamespy dying causing it to not have internet functions, I cant recomend it. Im sorry but this game gets beat out by MoWAS2. If MoWAS2 didnt exist then I would recomend this but I just I cant. Get this if you have the money, or if its on sale,  otherwise just get MoWAS2.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I'm going to be brutally honest here. I thought I was going to love this game, but I really don't. Everybody in all of the other reviews say how hard it is, and they're right. It's insanely difficult, but for stupid reasons. Whenever you tell your men to get into cover, they might do it and they might not. Whenever you tell your men to move from cover to cover while you're under fire, they will stop halfway, stand right out in the open, and get slaughtered, every single time, no matter how many times you tell them to keep moving. An entire squad of men will die in an instant, because they didn't do what you told them to do. This could be all my fault, because there are so many buttons to use that they had to resort to combinations of buttons to do even more things. Trying to remember what all the buttons do, is like trying to learn a new language. If I were going to learn a new language, it would be whatever language this game was programed in, so I could add a new button. I would call it, just do what i say, and when I push it, my men would have to do what I say. I've only played this game for a few hours, and I don't even know how many times I lost, because my men wouldn't do what I told them to do. I can't even begin to explain how frustrating that is. I honestly had to go smoke, because I was getting so mad. I can see how a lot of people really like this game, and ten bucks is a good price for it, but Company of Heroes is also ten bucks, and it's so much better. SO MUCH BETTER. I recommend that instead.SUMMARY-You will lose, many, many times, simply because your men won't listen to you. It honestly felt like I was telling a kid to do their chores. It's just a losing battle.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Bought this in the bundle, so I don't feel I've wasted too much money on this game.I know, the time I spent on this game isn't too much. I'm still trying to play it.The game feels nice at first, but after a while you see all the bugs and lack of common sense among your soldiers that you want to throw your computer through the window.Your soldiers did a good fight, but end up without ammo, what do you do?Micromanage your units to refill their ammo! I know, realism... But in realistic game you would just put an ammo truck nearby your squad, so they can refill their ammo, and your units would do it!The amount of problems with pathfinding among your soldiers is so huge, it really ruins the experience with this game.You want to move your mortar unit?Gah! They can't move through there!You got a brand new and shiny m8 greyhound straight from factory!Bam! It is stuck on the streetlamp! Points wasted cause enemy comes and destroys it!Micromanagement would not be that bad in this game if your soldiers had some common sense so you could leave them alone for some time.I remember, that in original MoW soldiers weren't too bright, but you were in the control of smaller squads, so could pay them your full attention.What is nice in this game?Japanese campaign!

content:
Posted: January 26
												The Men of War series of games are the exact same game, with different units and maps. There is no real difference between them.  So it doesn't realy matter which one you get. I have played All of them several times, including vietnam and assault squad 2. HOWEVER when you have purchased one title, please trim your fingernails and ductape them, otherwise you risk scratching your own face of, out of frustration over this game.First to the things that this game does right:+ Direct control of a unit - To be able to take control of a unit is fun, efficient and a nice feature that enables players who are not into RTS to accualy participate in the game as a coop unit.+ Sounds and graphic - This game feels very much like a real warzone, the sounds, explosions, fire, destruction of terrain and especialy the vehicles are excellent and there realy is no title quite like it. + Vehicle and hit zones - All vehicles have different vulnerability at different parts of it (like in WOT). Different parts of the vehicle can be disabled and will effect the performance of it depending on which part. For example, take out the tracks = no movement, damage turret = turret can't turn (cannon can still fire)+ Mission diversity - Im very impressed with the engine, because the very same engine that runs the small stealth missions, is also handeling the huge battles. The mission have a huge variety which enables all the titles of men of war to be almost equaly enjoyable.Now to the bad things <:,(- THE STUPID♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI! - This is by far the worst downside of this game, all positive aspects of this game is dwarfed by this horrible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ babylike thing. It doesn't take long to realise that your units will almost NEVER complete the most simple of orders. so multiple duplications of the same orders have to be issued for them to complete one. Im not talking about advanced orders here like minelaying or rearming. Im talking about simple attack, movement orders. They will also refuse to do some orders completely and some of the assigned orders have been out of order (spread out which has been avalible for all titles) since the very first title, nothing accualy happens when you push the assigned key. Medics don't heal unless clicking every single unit that has been downed. the list goes on and on and ON! Men of War has by far the worst AI I have ever seen in any game in my entire life (and I played games for more than 25 years). - Too advanced controls - The ability to control every unit of this game to such detailness as in this game is a double edged sword. To deal with the stupid AI, it is necessary to have advanced controls. However it also gives the game a very hard learningcurve. and a very simple misstake with handeling your units can cost you the victory in an entire game, both multiplayer and singleplayer.- Optimisation - This game despite haveing an old engine tends to cramp up when too much things are happening at the same time in one screen. I do believe the reason for most singleplayer missions to be small is due to this game not being optimized. The physics enginee gets overheated quickly when too much is happening at the same time, this combined with freecamera rotation can make it possible to crash the game if you tilt it too much so it reavels to great of an area of the map.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												Could have been a great game. I only really play for single player, and the campaign missions are really dull and unimaginative. It is literally a 'copy and paste' job:-Go take over 1st line of flags to earn points for reinforcements-Enemy send troops and a tank when you capture a flag-Enemy tank is usually SLIGHTLY better than what you can afford or recruit-Finally get enough points or decent reinforcements, gets destroyed and then you have to wait until your points rack up again-Clear second line of flags-Repeat the above process for each flagDisappointed that virtually EVERY single level I have played so far has been the same. I can actually feel myself droning when I see the map and flags load up. The only saving grace is the map editor, but even then, it's not much better than the original Men of War editor and costs £4 less, plus the missions were more varied!

												I'll make this review simple.  There is no bots/ way of training for skrimishes.  You want to understand how to play before you face people that have played hundreds of games, too bad and screw you.  You don't get something in half a second, screw you and die.  Don't understand how the cover system works when half your squad runs forward, while the rest sits back and chills, screw you.  Don't get how to heal your units, screw you.  The long and short is, if you are like me and want to play a game for a half hour and chill at night.  This is not for you.  If you are a raging 13 year old who communicates via TeamSpeak and other BS online methods who can play 24/7, maybe this game is for you. content:
Posted: February 5
												Terrible AI. Terrible R&G once the unit count goes up beyond a certain limit. Lost a Tiger and a captured Pounder gun to a single Firefly, despite the fact I had a defensive advantage, go figure. I guess the game starts making leaps in calculating hit chances, damage and what not once the engine can't reasonably handle the number of units on the battlefield. I bought this game based on the recommendation of a friend, that it was very realistic and a great combat simulator overall. Now I see its not the case. Multiplayer is dead and Singleplayer is pretty much a slugfest with the AI, it just boils down to who can spam better. Might give MoW AS 2 a try, though I heard its pretty much the same.  Anyway, I don't recommend anyone to buy this game. Buy the newer one, or buy something else, I don't really care. But know that if you buy this game the only thing you're getting out of it is a horrible AI and a dead MP, a carcass of a game. Nothing more.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												This game is amazing, but with the recent closure of the online servers it is hardly worth getting unless you have friends that you can play with on a LAN network. The singleplayer skirmishes are dull and arent that challenging after you have completed a couple of missions. Its repetative and you feel like you are playing against a very old and slow computer. The computer doesnt punish you enough to make it challenging. You certainly cant play just the singleplayer on this game. The greatest part of the game is the multiplayer, but since that has been taken out of the game it has turned the game to trash. I cannot explain how much they destroyed the game by closing down the servers once MoW AS 2 came out. Dont get me wrong, I did enjoy playing this game a lot with mates. It is a laugh and can be some epic battles. I would absolutely reccomend this game if you have a bunch of friends that you see regularly. If you dont have mates that would come around to play, dont worry about getting it as it needs multiplayer to be enjoyable.If you absolutletly wanted a game like this then buy MoW AS 2 because this one just isnt enjoyable for long periods of time like it used to be.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												While it's an interesting game, there is a very steep learning curve. For someone who loves RTS games but sucks at PVP, this was a sorry disappointment when I learned I could not play cooperatively with a friend.The interface is wonky. It's difficult to select squads of troops and common controls like shift-click to select and deselect individual units do not function. The campaigns are incredibly frustrating even on easy due to very narrow maps an inability to flank your opponent. Furthermore the campaign is scripted and tedious even when you beat your opponent. It's a relentless process of bulking up your forces and smashing the enemy's defenses head on (because you can't flank) and then waiting two or three hours with no fast-forward while scripted enemy attacks send predictable waves of troops and tanks at you. That isn't strategy. That's turtle tactics followed by spam.Multiplayer options are harshly limited. There's no CPU players. Manpower points (currency to buy units) are extremely unclear. I don't know how to view how many you have or at what rate you gain more. Command points (value of units you are allowed to command) default to 80 which is barely enough for a couple of tanks, much less troops to support them. The max, which I think is 160 or 180 or something, still limits the size of your army more than I like. There's only one game mode and it's capture the points. What happened to bases? I'd like an enemy base to go destroy and experience a real feeling of victory. Not sit on a flag until the timer runs out in a glorified King of the Hill RTS.Men of War 2 is allegedly going to have cooperative gameplay. I look forward to this. Don't get me wrong--the concept of the game is a good one. But, don't spend your money on this unless there's a good sale going on. Otherwise maybe the sequel will be better. This one is interesting enough for me to be interested in the sequel.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Interesting game, with lots of possibilities. Right up front, this game establishes itself as a hybrid RTS/Third Person Shooter allowing players to take control of individual units - tons of fun.This game utterly fails in that it forces players to micromanage their units constantly. Individual Soldiers will often get weapons shot out of their hand, and will not automatically pick up a new weapon. Players must constantly manage resources as well (fuel, ammunition). Vehicles have insanely unrealistic fuel consumption rates which forces players to scavenge fuel from 'dead' vehicles. I think I understand where MoW was trying to go, but I feel that the micromanagement piece just takes too much away from the fact that this is a combat strategy game. Combat should be the focus not exorbant micromanagement of all of my units.

Posted: September 13, 2013
												Best game series ever. See a building? Blow it up with a well placed artillery/tank shell. No? How about ramming your ♥♥♥♥ing tank into it, taking it down with any other person inside? What about shrapnels? Do you like shrapnels? I ♥♥♥♥ing love shrapnels. All explosions are not based on the laughable spherical "blast radiuses" but on flying razors that can cut your men 7 ways to sunday. If one of your unlucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s happens to be having his head over the trench when an artillery shell hits his position or a grenade hits the top side, you better ♥♥♥♥ing hope he's wearing a helmet and ducking or else you're going to have to scoop that♥♥♥♥♥♥for a brain of his off the ground. Disabled an enemy tank? Oh my, well did you know that you can open its inventory, take out that machine gun and ammo, then blast the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the enemy? What about the fact that you can repair it on the field and use it as your own? What about the fact that EACH tank and vehicle has REALISTIC armor, sloping armor (that actually worK), and vital spots (ammo storage, fuel storage, etc.)? You can blow off their ♥♥♥♥ing tracks, turrets, and barrels for crying out loud! The vehicles do not operate on the basis of the Company of Heroes "health bars" but on the basis of reality. Soldiers do no damage with their rifles. Tanks get damaged based on where they hit with parts breaking down, hulls being pierced, and hulls being blown to bits.The game puts Company of Heroes to utter devastating shame. Get it. Men of War: Assault Squad is the most refined of the series with the ability to call in reinforcements and so on. I prefer the older ones (Men of War, Men of War: Red Tide, etc.) as ammo and infantry are scarce, you are forced to scavenge, repair, and loot dead bodies for cartridges, tank shells, fuel, and so on. Good micromanagement.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												I think its important that you undertsand that i REALLY wanna love this game, it has so much depth to it, but i just can't. What am i talking about? Well lets just get down to it.The game focuses on a "reinforcements" system like waves in a horde game, where you can buy reinforcements for the points you get from the flags on the map. These flags also unlock new toys to play with, and turns the point in your favour, giving you turrets and such pointing in the opposite direction. There are several "clans" to choose from, each having their own 'special' heavy weapons. There are the USA, Nazi Germany, Soviet Russia, The Japanese, And the Common Wealth, each having their own levels and obstacles.The game focuses on 'realistic' warfare, though i will say its much more realistic than Company Of Heroes, as each soldier has a bag pack with ammo, helmet, shovel, you name it. They can be divided into smaller or bigger squad of units or be controlled by the player in a simplistic way if you find that the soldier's aim is off. They have their own health bars and can do anything themselfs without relying on their squad to follow them, so you can take the rocketeer out of your squad, take manual control of him, run around your position, and blow up whatever that was pinning you down. Soldiers will even keep their head low while under heavy fire and sometimes heal themselfs in mid combat *Something that is allways useful when you're busy micro managing*.smaller Anti fortification and tank machines like mortars are also dynamic, as you can damage several parts of the map to clear a shot for your soldiers, or break a certain part of a tank. Is a tank Plowing down your formation? aim for the trackers. Is the gunner constantly cathing your soldiers? Order your soldiers to aim for the gunner turret. Not only does it feel amazing, its also neccesary to keep your waves up. Now... For the bad things. Remember how i mentioned the Ai is quite dynamic? Yeah, that's 30% of the time. The other 70% they will stand and glare at you before actually opening fire, or they will stand still INFRONT OF A TANK waiting for the 'throw grenade' animation to start. SPEAKING OF WHICH! One of the most important parts of the infantry is the ability to quickly get around or get rid of Armored targets, well somebody at 1C COMPANY must have had a good time when he decided your soldiers wouldn't be able to make up its own bloody mind when you send it to throw a grenade at a tank, leaving them 80% crawling slowly towards it while you furiously click on the 'stand up and charge it' button, leaving them open for a gang r^^e by turrets.Remember i mentioned this game is dynamic? Yeah, its so dynamic it dosen't even tell you what's good against what. Oh suuuure it gives you a in-depth look of how big the gun is, or how thick the armor is on the left side of what you're viewing, but if you don't know anything before hand about WORLD WAR 2, you're basically left to guess as to which tank is good against which. So you better whip out those WORLD WAR 2 war books kids, or else you'll be fu^^^^ harder than the Japanese fleet when they first fought the Americans.I really do think you can have a great time in this game, and there are a LOT of hours to be had here, but the AI problems and the lack of tutorilization on all the Panzer just leaves me with a sour taste in my mouth. I will however reccomend the game to you if you have ever wanted the Big Name countrys from world war 2 to band together and destroy some evil snowman tanks, or make a steak for the summer peace festival.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												This game embodies the best formula for a strategy game to date. The gameplay allows for the greatest flexibility of any army, allowing for the maximum replayability and some of the most intesnese multiplayer skirmishes i've played.A simple well-placed infantryman can take out the heaviest tank with a single AT grenade. This is a good example of how the game lets you utilize units in the best way possible. Direct control allows the player to take command of any unit on the battlefield. Take a machine gun in order to better suppress the enemy, or command a panzer in a daring flank tactic.All in all this game is amazing, and one of the best game's ive played.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												My opinion of Men of War: Assault Squad. I want to first start by saying that this game is well made. The game developers really took their time to evalute what can make this game a great title for the genre. I believe that a game like Company of Heros has nothing on Men of War as MoW has much more to offer. Pros: Variety of units to choose from. Game depth. From Squad command to individual control.Graphics and depthness of field.The physics are good for this type of game.Really well-made game in my opinion.Replayability. Which I think is the most important.Cons:Being a mainly Multiplayer game it should have a better multiplayer interface than gamespy.Once you complete the AI skirmishes, not much to do except buy DLCs, in terms of Computer vs Player.The AI itself isint the brightest. Could be better.Other than these cons there are a few smaller ones but I do not think they are worth mentioning.With the Part 2 comming out shortly, I hope that some of the kinks are worked out in the game and there is even more varied content from unit control to variety of units. With a new Multiplayer interface being the most important improvement I would make on a game like this. Especially some kinda offical server or matchmaking.I do recommend this game having about 200 hours played as of this review. Good clean fun.

There is a massive sense of front line fighting in the game too.The destruction is amazing! Hiding behind buildings, walls and trees or even high grass can not save you from Artillery! This game sets the standard for RTS. It is great

Posted: June 30, 2013
												Buy this if you enjoy hardcore WW2 RTS action. The Editor alone is awesome if you learn how to use it, you can create your own battles and play them in the editor while still being able to place units/objects. Noteworthy is that the battles can go for aslong as you want if played on easy and to some extent normal, if your a slower-paced game. Though this game is very hard and you will find yourself using real tactics. Assault Squad is easier than the original because its not a campaign but more a sequence of battles where YOU control the types of units you have. Wait for 10 panthers or charge russian style with infantry, totally up to you. Very very fun game and LOTS of units to choose from.

												It's a great game! Really has some intense combat situations were if you panic, you're dead. Also has some great features and silly ways to destroy the enemy like throwing hand grenades into open top tanks to hit the ammo. No unit is invincible, yet some if not many do not fall easily to frontal attacks.Plenty of variety, has modding material, 40+maps, DLC is cheap, it's a great buy.Worth having in your library.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												I will say that after playing countless hours of this game, it is one of the best RTS style games ive come across, provided you are willing to use mods or create your own mods to supplement its lack of proper single player missions and fix some of the minor bugs that still exist.  While i just got a steam version (as the other retail one ive been using broke and i lost CD), so my hours on here may not appear like ive played this much despite having teh game beforehand.Unlike almost all RTS style games, this features direct control, and just like SHOWW2, an exceptional game for its time, makes combat alot more interesting then the usual point-click to tell a unit to go somewhere or attack a target.  You can manually engage cerain targets, drive yourself with WSAD, and control aspects liek reloading weapon, switching shell types, ect all manually.The armor damage modeling is great, and while a couple bugs do exist, with the rare tank that refuses to die to anything but dynamite, overall tanks behave like you would expect them to behave in say games such a WOT or WT (although even those arent 100% realistic when it comes to shell properties and penetration).  There are a few minor inconsistencies, here and there, and weakspots arent modeled, but overall great.With modded missions (or ones you make yourself) the game is truly amazing.  Many custom missions use units from teh game that are never deployed by the standard missions (for examle panzer 1, archer, jagdtiger, ect).  Some also are true campaign maps, such as the MoW 1 campaign port, and others.  The base game is exceptional when it comes to tools and resources it provides, but its default set of missions (even the DLC missions) tend to be rather repetitive, and aside from a different map, most of them feature the exact same set of units.The squad mechanic is very nice, units within a squad share ammunition, and will resupply evenly when picking ammo out of trucks or dead guys.  Its also possible to disable this squad featurem, and have the selection system function more like the old SHOWW2 with individual soldiers separate from each other.  There is one particular bug that was present since the original MoW game, and apparently has never been "officially" fixed.  The tanks do on occasion get stuck refusing to target anything until either manually controlled, or given a direct order to fire at something.  Its a quick fix with a mod i made, but its kindof sad to see a bug that can be fixed by anyone who bothers to actually open up some game files and look at the targeting code to fix.  One single .cfg file that repairs this issue.  Another minor bug (again fixable with a 1 minute .cfg edit) if the flamethrower infantry refusing to attack anything outside of manual control.  Perhaps this is intentional, as fully AI flamethrowers tend to ignite anything in between them and their target, but id still say their blatant refusal to fire is a bug.Finally, while not technically a bug, the AI in the game is rather primitive.  Dont get me wrong, with a few hours in teh editor ive managed to make the AI much better, but it would be nice if the devs actually spent a little bit more time improving AI, especially pathing on some MP maps (how annoying is it to send out a AT gun, and find it stuck up a tree near spawn when you needed it the most).  Also, with proper scripting in the missions, AI is able to repair damaged tanks, retreat and regroup when their squads are mostly wiped out, be agressive and defensive with the right situations, and just be a much bigger threat, but these things all need to be manually scripted into missions, and these arent automatically done by the AI, and many things like waypoints need to be tweaked on many maps to keep tanks from driving off staircases and flipping upsidedown (looking at 1st russian skirmish mission).  AI could use a major overhaul, and after trying AS-2 on a friend's machine, i have to say it hasnt improved at all in a game that at least on paper is support to be a true sequel (more like a large patch/DLC that shouldnt be more then $10).The default missions are rather repetitive, and even that is an understatement.  For example the USA campaign's 1st 3 missions are carbon copies of each other, every mission you get the exact same lineup of tanks, the exact same infanrty options, the exact same AT gun, ect, and the enemy is always the same, every mission you face the exact same german tanks, and the exact same infanrty at any given difficulty.  Yes the maps change, and one of them happens to have winter camo on vehicles, but aside from some maps being more open, and some being more urban styled, every single game is pretty much identical.  Now with mods, this can change, personally i run custom modded missions that vary the unitset, and actually add more unit options for friendly reinforcements, making the game less stale, and making each mission different, with some being more tank based, others infantry based, and also all of them having historical unit sets, with things like the sherman firefly removed from africa missions (firefly according to my knowledge wasnt ever deployed in africa).  With mods, the game is great, but without mods, not so much.Finally, while a minor thing that is fixed with my mods, the difficulty settings dont seem to scale that well in this game.  Easy is a complete joke, and normal isnt that easy, but seems to cut out all the somewhat hard to kill tanks.  Hard/Heroic are more my level, but the biggest issue ive found on these difficulties is so called infantry spam, where you literally have to deal with so much infantry a Wirbelwind will more or less be shooting non-stop, assuming it doesnt get killed by the tank rushes.  The difficulty ramping is alot a little bit out of whack, on hard/heroic, the missions are extremely tough initially, with the enemy having access to their top vehicles right from the start.  Expect alot and i mean ALOT of reloading saves on hard or heroic difficulty, as this level makes loosing just one tank lead to defeat.In conclusion, the game provided a very good toolset and baseline for many mods, but sadly, the default missions are a little bit stale, especially if you expected a true single player game that like its predecessors has some storyline, or varying missions that are different from each other and other nations.  The amount of bugs is very minor, all of them fixable with mods.  The AI is above average, and while they arent scripted that great in the stock missions, they are still a challenge, capable of swarming a position you left unguarded, or defending the spot that you are assaulting fairly well.  The direct control and vast array of units are why ive always enjoyed the entire series all the way back with SHOWW2, a truly great game, that this massively expands upon in so many ways.  The squad selection and better inventory management is a great improvement from SHOWW2.  I strongly reccomend this game, even over Assault-Squad 2, when its on sale.  75% off, its around $4, and its so cheap, that anyone who is interested in this series shoudl start here.  AS-1 features many mods, has been around long enough that the majority of bugs have been patched out, and is in my opinion teh best game in the series.  If you are looking for online MP, then i have to say you must get the sequel (err overpriced DLC), its the exact same game minus like 3 or so new vehicles, a couple HD models, and some reskins for soldier camo (which anyone with MSpaint can make in 10 minutes).  LAN gaming or direct-IP connections still work, so if you have friends, MP still functions, and is arguable less buggy then the so called sequel.  FInally, i suggest against getting the game of teh year edition as the missions there arent needed for using mods, where imo all the fun stuff is at.  The only reason i got it myself is for modding resources.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												I have a love/hate relationship with the Men of War series in general.  On the one hand, if you are looking for an accessible World War 2 RTS that focuses on tactics and realism there is really no other option.  On the other, the game can be such an unbalanced mess with dumb AI that it will make your head spin.The main issue with MoW: AS is that the developer can never seem to get the game quite right in terms of balance or content.  It feels as if they just had a bigger budget or better research the game would be amazing.  As it stands the game only really shines if you mod it and there are quite a few good ones out there.  I would only recommend MoW:AS if you are already a fan of the series and are willing to mod the game or you find it on a Steam sale and want to try a World War II RTS other than the "arcadey" Company of Heroes.

Posted: June 2, 2011
												A mortar is an indirect fire weapon that fires shells at low velocities, short ranges, and high-arcing ballistic trajectories. It is typically muzzle-loading and has a barrel length less than 15 times its caliber. A mortar is relatively simple and easy to operate. A modern mortar consists of a tube into which gunners drop a shell, which is usually referred to as a bomb. The shell contains a quantity of propellant. When it reaches the base of the tube it hits a firing pin, which detonates the propellant and fires the shell. Some larger caliber mortars have a string operated firing pin instead of a fixed one. The tube is generally set at between 45 and 85 degrees angle to the ground, with the higher angle giving shorter firing distances.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												My opinion of Men of War: Assault Squad. I want to first start by saying that this game is well made. The game developers really took their time to evalute what can make this game a great title for the genre. I believe that a game like Company of Heros has nothing on Men of War as MoW has much more to offer. Pros: Variety of units to choose from. Game depth. From Squad command to individual control.Graphics and depthness of field.The physics are good for this type of game.Really well-made game in my opinion.Replayability. Which I think is the most important.Cons:Being a mainly Multiplayer game it should have a better multiplayer interface than gamespy.Once you complete the AI skirmishes, not much to do except buy DLCs, in terms of Computer vs Player.The AI itself isint the brightest. Could be better.Other than these cons there are a few smaller ones but I do not think they are worth mentioning.With the Part 2 comming out shortly, I hope that some of the kinks are worked out in the game and there is even more varied content from unit control to variety of units. With a new Multiplayer interface being the most important improvement I would make on a game like this. Especially some kinda offical server or matchmaking.I do recommend this game having about 200 hours played as of this review. Good clean fun.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Okay, for a small review for people who just want a short overall review, I give this an 8/10 due to its realistic workings, but buggyish AI and performance issues.But if you want, I will tell you a bit more in detail.Men of War: Assault Squad is a game that is oreinted around multiplayer(Although I wish it had a bit more work for the skirmishes and possibly a campaign). Its in WW2 and it has 5 factions. USA, Soviet Union, Germany, Japan and Commonwealth. Japan is the new faction introduced in this game. Overall, the game is realistic to the max, with lifelike workings and atmospheric battles. The only things that make up cons is the somewhat buggy AI and performance issues.Pros:Realistic battles.Atmospheric battles.Large skirmish campaign.Decent multiplayer.Decent amount of factions.Overall great RTS experience.Cons:Somewhat buggy AI.Performance issues.No story campaign(Although I know its not oreinted around it, but it would of been nice).For examples on the AI, I was on the first Soviet Union skirmish battle and I got one of the APC things. I moved it to a bridge and then tended to some units across the bridge. I came back to it and found it hanging off the side of the bridge. Tried to move it, didn't budge. Then I ordered the units to get out onto the bridge. It took me around 10-15 minutes to get them all out, and one of them went the totally opposite way and jumped off the bridge. Ive had some other misc. AI problems, but those are just common little problems. Thats why I said somewhat buggy AI, not completely buggy or bad AI.Hope this helped, and you should buy for sure.8/10Well, between 8/10 and 8.5/10.So basically, I recommend to get this if you can handle a bit of lag and slightly buggy AI.

Posted: December 11, 2011
												Assault Squad is pure, gritty, and often unpredictable, battlefield strategy. Tank combat is seriously satisfying and the ability to directly control any unit opens up a degree of precision not possible in other titles. However, the learning curve is steep; the gameplay principles and mechanics will initially feel unnecessarily complex, demanding an unprecedented level of micro-management and awareness. The plethora of units to choose from, overwhelming and mistakes are unforgiving. Past that curve though, lies a deeply rewarding experience where the realism and intricacies of the game become extremely immersive.

Posted: September 9, 2014
												Great game, but definitely not for competitive players. By that I mean if you're like me and you hate losing, you should look elsewhere for your wargaming. The AI is apparently managed by The Amazing Kreskin because they know exactly where you are at all times and exactly which units you have. If you make a move, they react immediately and without hesitation. This usually ends with a total failure in 90% of your missions. You will be restarting over and over for hours on end. Oh did I mention this is on Normal difficulty? I'm not sure why they would even include the Hard or Heroic difficulties because I can't imagine it being remotely fun. As far as I know, on Heroic the enemy would have pocket nuclear bombs, laser guided missiles and stealth bombers. During WWII. There are certain missions where you will literally gasp at how completely you get beaten by the AI. There is no time to dig in because the longer you wait, the more tanks they bring out. I have never seen the AI run out of tanks either. On the campaign mission 'Overlord' for example I had 33 enemy tanks and tank destroyers on the map. Yes, 33 of them - I counted because I didn't think it possible. Granted they didn't get 33 out at once, but they had that many in reserve and until the very end of the mission they kept rolling them out two at a time, every few minutes. You will have enough Reinforcement Points for at most 10 tanks/tank destroyers, and that is only if you last long enough. The real kicker is when you complete around 80% of your mission objectives the AI will throw everything they have at you, and each soldier is a military genius. Seriously, any AI grunt unit in this game would make Erwin Rommel look like a mental midget. Not to mention It takes just one single grunt to run up to your capture point and the game is over, mission failed. There is no "turnaround time" or anything. You either have the capture point or you don't. There is a "flag raising" animation when you capture or lose a point, but it's just for show and is not a timer - If the flag begins to move, it's over for either you or the enemy (99% of the time it's you).

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Spent 2 hours collecting chickens, Beef, and Crates of Beer, while fighting Rebels.Best 2 hours spent in several years.Serious Review:Pros:-Old-School inventory management, which is very refined and is rarely bothersome-Realistic Ballistics in combat, be it Vehicular or Infantry-Takes some common sense to play-Hilariously out of place Bonus Missions-Endless Strategy available-Sturmtiger. 'nuf said-Better AI than most modern AAA titles-Very well balanced-Long campaign, due to some battles taking a few hours to do, as the AI, though not UBERHAXRNOVA, WILL punish you for leaving a gap in defences, and will counter your units very nicely.-Good learning curve-Outstanding graphics for a game of it's time, much better than other RTS titles released later -Very good economy system-Rarely overwhelming, the Minimap helps alot too, as it let's you plan ahead in the battle, and stay up-to-date on enemy Movements-Destructible cover, buildings, etc...-Murphy's Laws occur on anything and everything mechanical. Seriously.-Vehicles can be repaired after taking damage, but don't expect to have a quick repair, at least not after any kind of serious damage.-Vehicles can run out of fuel, adding a huge tactical element (Dang it Germany, Y U NO USE JAPANESE CARS!? )-Well populated map with lots of nooks and crannies to explore and setup mortars and other Defences-Awesomely huge fighting when it turns into an infantry-based battle, with ALOT going on.-Real sense of accomplishment when you complete a long, intense, battle against all odds-Runs on Windows 8/8.1 without any issues-Great ingame music-Very well optimized, even for lower-end, aging machinesCons:-A battle on harder difficulties can last 4-5 hours towards the end of the game, so this can go either way-Can get campy-ish towards the end of a mission, due to the AT guns and the trenches,etc..

Posted: March 23, 2015
												I have a love/hate relationship with the Men of War series in general.  On the one hand, if you are looking for an accessible World War 2 RTS that focuses on tactics and realism there is really no other option.  On the other, the game can be such an unbalanced mess with dumb AI that it will make your head spin.The main issue with MoW: AS is that the developer can never seem to get the game quite right in terms of balance or content.  It feels as if they just had a bigger budget or better research the game would be amazing.  As it stands the game only really shines if you mod it and there are quite a few good ones out there.  I would only recommend MoW:AS if you are already a fan of the series and are willing to mod the game or you find it on a Steam sale and want to try a World War II RTS other than the "arcadey" Company of Heroes.

												MOW:AS (pronounced MO' A$$) is a fun and action-packed RTS game. You are able to command forces from Japan, Germany, England, the USA, and Soviet Russia through the campaign or against other players. Movement and deployment of units is intuitive and can be done from the perspective of the general or the unit itself. The one thing that's frustrating is when the enemy who you are attacking has artillery and especially anti-tank guns, when this situation arises it is almost impossible to resolve unless you are playing as Englend in which case you have the power to take those guns out with your own heavy artillery. Russia also has heavy artillery, but it is not as good.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												MoW: AS is a very tough RTS. You have the ability to control anything from a single soldier to an entire platoon. Combat is intensely realistic as a platoon of infantry in the open can be cut down in seconds. Tank on Tank combat is excessively realistic to the point where most players learn why many strategists would only use tanks with infantry escort. Tracks can get blown off, guns can get destroyed, crew can get sniped from inside of the tank, and ammo racks can detonate, all depending on where a shot is placed. If a tank is damaged, it can be abandoned, or the crew can leave the tank to repair it and get back in.Aside from Tank on Tank combat, Infantry combat also feels very fleshed out. Units can and will be suppresed (however, there will be no alert, they will all simply just fall to the ground and crawl to the nearest waypoint you set for them), as well as realistic logistics. No unit has infinite ammunition supplies, and if you're running low, your best option is to loot an enemy's corpse for extra ammunition, as ammunition types are universal amongst weapons with examples such as: Rifle Ammo, Pistol Ammo,  Shotshells, Machine gun belts, ect. This may not be completely realistic, but it's enough to keep the game steamlined just enough to keep gameplay fun, but not mindless.My only complaints are:- There is no Players vs. AI settings in the game- Server connection is absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ You will constantly get a message saying "Connecting to server" every fifteen to twenty second. It lags the game for a half second to two full seconds, and is definitely enough to ruin the intensity of a big firefight.- Units are hardly autonomous. Unless you purposely want units to sit in a defensive position, you have to intensely micromanage your troops and vehicles. If you leave any unit sitting idle for long enough, it WILL be killed.- In multiplayer matches, there is no "deep striking" infantry unit (like American paratroopers in CoH) that can spawn where you click on the field. 173rd Airborne and Fallshirmjager are just basically elite infantry units, and hold no strategic value over your typical run-of-the-mill G.I.'s or Grenadiers.Overall the game is great, but the lack of the Player vs. AI option kills it imho. I'd recommend this only so a friend can have a taste of what a true WWII FPS should feel like, only to go back and play with what MoW: AS had failed to compete against.

Once I got the tank in a made quick work of it, but then meir seconds later a enemy rock hits my tank and destroys it. 												Okay, for a small review for people who just want a short overall review, I give this an 8/10 due to its realistic workings, but buggyish AI and performance issues.But if you want, I will tell you a bit more in detail.Men of War: Assault Squad is a game that is oreinted around multiplayer(Although I wish it had a bit more work for the skirmishes and possibly a campaign). Its in WW2 and it has 5 factions. USA, Soviet Union, Germany, Japan and Commonwealth. Japan is the new faction introduced in this game. Overall, the game is realistic to the max, with lifelike workings and atmospheric battles. The only things that make up cons is the somewhat buggy AI and performance issues.Pros:Realistic battles.Atmospheric battles.Large skirmish campaign.Decent multiplayer.Decent amount of factions.Overall great RTS experience.Cons:Somewhat buggy AI.Performance issues.No story campaign(Although I know its not oreinted around it, but it would of been nice).For examples on the AI, I was on the first Soviet Union skirmish battle and I got one of the APC things. I moved it to a bridge and then tended to some units across the bridge. I came back to it and found it hanging off the side of the bridge. Tried to move it, didn't budge. Then I ordered the units to get out onto the bridge. It took me around 10-15 minutes to get them all out, and one of them went the totally opposite way and jumped off the bridge. Ive had some other misc. AI problems, but those are just common little problems. Thats why I said somewhat buggy AI, not completely buggy or bad AI.Hope this helped, and you should buy for sure.8/10Well, between 8/10 and 8.5/10.So basically, I recommend to get this if you can handle a bit of lag and slightly buggy AI.

Posted: November 3, 2015
For who Men of War: Assault Squad is best suited : - World War 2 enthusiasts who enjoy a more immersive gameplay experience; players who find Company of Heroes to be way too casual; and PC Strategy gamers who aren't afraid of a challenge. Quick Summary: - Tactical, strategic, detailed, complex, challenging, and realistic style of game-play where battles actually feel like war, troops feel like individual soldiers, and you will feel like a great general coordinating it all. Very refreshing since most RTS games on the market tend to boil down to a simple blob-based brute force combat system. Not here! - Features extremely impressive cover based (best I've ever seen), destruction, and combat systems superior to its direct competitor (Company of Heroes) with a graphical engine that can be considered its equal if not greater due to a more pleasing zoomed out camera in Men of War. - Comes with a decent but far from perfect user-interface. - Doesn't feature a true single player narrative campaign, but rather a "skirmish" game-mode when it comes to single-player. In that sense it can be considered a more of a multi-player centric experience (either against other humans; coop with friend(s) against the AI; or you taking on a single AI solo). - Probably its only true weakness is the game suffers from some unnecessarily complex resupply mechanics. Really, its too complex and tedious for a real-time strategy game on this scale. It seems to be a left over relic from the earlier Men of War games which were based more on small squad oriented gameplay (like the Commando's series.) Final Thoughts: What 1C was able to create here is a truly impressive feat and I highly recommend at least giving the demo a try. It features one of the single-player skirmish maps and will give you a great sense of what Men of War Assault Squad is all about.

Posted: August 27, 2016
												If, like me, you've been looking around for a brilliant, satisfying WW2 game, which is not really bias, and reasonably realistic, then look no further friend.Men of War: Assault Squad, was a sale bought gem which, finally, sated the void that Company of heroes left. In RTS games nothing is more infuriating than watching your soldiers shoot down a health bar, like something out of bloody runescape. Not in this game, no sir. You charge a machine gun with your squad? That squad is 99% certain of being mown down in seconds. Instead this game does what most RTS's don't, it forces you to learn, adapt, and become efficient at managing multiple units accurately. Unlike company of heroes, when they talk about needed combined arms to advance, they really mean it here. You'll need to learn the best ways to knock out anti-tank guns, which is usually done by tank rushes, mortars, or massed infantry assaults, (the middle is the best way i find). You'll need to learn to deal with a constant flow of enemies, both entrenched and counter attacks.And best of all is the tank combat. MY GOD, have they done it brilliantly. Gone are the days of watching tanks playing AP ping pong until a health bar dissapears, now you can lose you tank in one shot from an anti-tank gun. You can also wreck said anti-tank gun with a well placed HE round. This game has so much to worry yourself about, and you'll love it.Battles are stressful, but addictive, loses are a certainty, getting good at this game will simply keep them to a minimum, and if you're looking to see something portray WW2 as an era of time thats not just "Germans had tigers and Americans were the best" then welcome aboard.You can only play single player, as the developers have sunken all their energy into the new game, which I guess isn't bad, and the only drawbacks I had was the lack of maps for Skirmish. Each factions has 4 or 5 missions, and as I want to only play as the commonwealth, which really should be called the British Empire ¬_¬ that doesn't leave a lot to do. But this is a game where even easy mode is challanging so I've plenty to do. You don't need a top whack PC to run this, which is great. All in all, a very satisfying game, especially when you take into account the ability to repair vehicle wrecks, the inventory system, the fluid combat system, realisitc combat and amount of thinking you need to do.

												So, I picked this up for around 1$ during a steam summer sale. At the time i had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little laptop that could run csgo on medium settings with about 30 fps. I was able to run the game at all low settings with low fps.so ill list the pros and the cons:pros:- You can play it on most hardware- The editor is awsome- The gameplay is all ways engaging- You get the big five to play as (U.S, Britan, Germany, Russia, and Japan)- Infantry combat is one of the best parts for me, creating squads, and sending thim into battle- The textures are not bad for such an old game either - The modding commuty is amazing such as the Galaxy At War mod (A Starwars mod)Cons:- The multiplayer is dead, I mean you cant play multiplayer at all- Some models are quite, well, not good (Such as the faces)- Have to download seprate software to play with others (Such as Hamachi) - Dont even get me started on the single player missions - This game was ment to be played multiplayer, and you cant play multiplayer- The damn demo had better "missions" than the acutal game!If you have a better computer than a♥♥♥♥♥♥laptop I suggest getting Men Of War Assault Squad 2(BTW my computer is not a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop anymore cool right?)

Posted: October 12, 2016
												Although I am not much of a game critic, I must say this game is ♥♥♥♥ing phenomenal. The unit selection is very wide, with many different tanks, and support vehicles for every faction. As well as different variations of infantry, ranging from cheap rifle squads to elite infantry teams. The artillery in this game works ♥♥♥♥ing amazingly. Every time one of my howitzer rounds lands on a large group of infantry I feel a rush of satisfaction. If you are a fan of large scale rts games, especially realistic ones, and if you like micro management this is a game for you. I personally have an obsession with WW2 and have always wanted a game where I could command large groups of soldiers and tanks on the battlefield. And I have finally found it.I recommend this to any stratedgy lover with every fiber of my being. Just a little tip to anyone newer to the game, if you are having trouble figuring out how to play this game effectively, I recommend either reading up on the different unit stats, or just looking up some basic military stratedgies because this game is very reliant on historical accuracy of the different weapons and vehicles used in WW2. Every unit in this game has specific uses so if you don't understand how to use each of them proplerly you aren't going to last long whether it be against the AI in skirmish mode or real players in MP. Speaking of multiplayer, be sure to download gameranger or a similar client available, as GameSpy(the original multiplayer server host) is no longer in use.I hope this was helpful :D

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Okay, for a small review for people who just want a short overall review, I give this an 8/10 due to its realistic workings, but buggyish AI and performance issues.But if you want, I will tell you a bit more in detail.Men of War: Assault Squad is a game that is oreinted around multiplayer(Although I wish it had a bit more work for the skirmishes and possibly a campaign). Its in WW2 and it has 5 factions. USA, Soviet Union, Germany, Japan and Commonwealth. Japan is the new faction introduced in this game. Overall, the game is realistic to the max, with lifelike workings and atmospheric battles. The only things that make up cons is the somewhat buggy AI and performance issues.Pros:Realistic battles.Atmospheric battles.Large skirmish campaign.Decent multiplayer.Decent amount of factions.Overall great RTS experience.Cons:Somewhat buggy AI.Performance issues.No story campaign(Although I know its not oreinted around it, but it would of been nice).For examples on the AI, I was on the first Soviet Union skirmish battle and I got one of the APC things. I moved it to a bridge and then tended to some units across the bridge. I came back to it and found it hanging off the side of the bridge. Tried to move it, didn't budge. Then I ordered the units to get out onto the bridge. It took me around 10-15 minutes to get them all out, and one of them went the totally opposite way and jumped off the bridge. Ive had some other misc. AI problems, but those are just common little problems. Thats why I said somewhat buggy AI, not completely buggy or bad AI.Hope this helped, and you should buy for sure.8/10Well, between 8/10 and 8.5/10.So basically, I recommend to get this if you can handle a bit of lag and slightly buggy AI.

Posted: December 11, 2011
												Assault Squad is pure, gritty, and often unpredictable, battlefield strategy. Tank combat is seriously satisfying and the ability to directly control any unit opens up a degree of precision not possible in other titles. However, the learning curve is steep; the gameplay principles and mechanics will initially feel unnecessarily complex, demanding an unprecedented level of micro-management and awareness. The plethora of units to choose from, overwhelming and mistakes are unforgiving. Past that curve though, lies a deeply rewarding experience where the realism and intricacies of the game become extremely immersive.

Posted: November 21, 2015
												Men of War: Assault Squad builds upon several excellent games, bringing you one of the finest real time strategic combat experiences there exists. Several balanced factions to play with and a multitude of units available combined with the depth in the ballistic system and the destructible environment provides the players with a playground that enables some truly unique combat experiences. The skirmish single-player is very lacklustre, previous titles in the series provide much better campaigns on that front, but on the multi-player side the game is truly unmatched.

Posted: December 2, 2015
												Men of War: Assault Squad is a very detailed RTS game. This game demands alot of your time and brain. What makes Men of War so fun and different is how much you can customize your playing style. You will not be building bases or collection resources. Rather you will be fighting battles in World War II. The main goal of the missions is to capture bases and destroy the enemy. Sounds simple enough, but the catch is that you can only call in reinforcments with Manpower. Manpower is points you use to call in different types of units and support. Different units mean different prices. 1 squad of soldiers will cost 120 MP, while a tank will cost 300 to even 900 MP, depending on the tank. Every single soldier has his own name, inventory, and health. You will have to maintain your army and it's squads. This can be hard to keep up to date with the inventory of every soldier but thankfully there are ways to give out ammo easier, and soldiers will heal themselves with packs when injured. Also, the extreme amount of things you can customize can really change how you play and give you hundreds of new ways to play. Tanks also have a realistic damage system, which too also brings a great and powerful gameplay change from most RTS games.Maps are truly massive and it creates the feeling of truly being a general leading armies to defeat the enemy. Holes from shells will be created, trees fall, flames spread, sandbags being place, and far more carnage awaiting.Sound and Graphics are truly beautiful but the voice acting can be meh. The main complaints I have about this game is that there is no normal skirmish mode. Just alot of missions to play Single player, but no true campaign. with the servers gone and the medicore single player around I really do not suggest a buy unless you enjoy the gameplay and do not mind playing missions over and over. Missions are massive and can take hours to complete which is a plus, but once you finish them all, nothing else remains. However a huge plus is LAN games are still possible and huge fun, and that can truly make this game fun to play and give  alot of new experiences. If you are a RTS General willing to learn alot and have a very detailed RTS game. I suggest this game to you. If you are new to the RTS genre or play casual, I suggest something else.
